tgt_text.533: Now in engaging in war we ought to make it appear that we have no other view but peace.
tgt_text.534: But the character of a brave and resolute man is not to be ruffled with adversity, and not to be in such confusion as to quit his post, as we say, but to preserve a presence of mind, and the exercise of reason, without departing from his purpose.
tgt_text.535: And while this is the charac- teristic of a lofty spirit, so this also is that of a powerful intellect, namely, to anticipate futurity in thought, and to conclude beforehand what may happen on either side, and, upon that, what measures to pursue, and never be surprised so as to say, "I had not thought of that."
tgt_text.536: Such are the operations of a genius, capacious and elevated ;
tgt_text.537: of such a one as relies on its own prudence and counsel ;
tgt_text.538: † but to rush precipitately into the field, and to encounter an enemy with mere physical force has somewhat in it that is barbarous and brutal.
tgt_text.539: When the occasion, however, and its necessity compel it, we should resist with force, and prefer death to slavery or dishonour.
tgt_text.541: But with regard to overthrowing and plundering of cities, great consideration is required that nothing be done rashly, nothing cruelly.*
tgt_text.542: And this is the part of a great man, after he has maturely weighed all circumstances, to punish the guilty, to spare the many ;
tgt_text.543: and in every state of fortune not to depart from an upright, virtuous conduct.
tgt_text.544: For, as you find (as I have already observed) men who prefer military to civil duties, so will you find many of that cast wile look upon dangerous and violent resolutions to be more splendid and more dignified than calm and digested measures.
tgt_text.545: We should never so entirely avoid danger as to appear irresolute and cowardly ;
tgt_text.546: but, at the same time, we should avoid unnecessarily exposing ourselves to danger, than which nothing can be more foolish.
tgt_text.547: In encountering dangers, therefore, we are to imitate the practice of the physicians who apply to gentle illnesses gentle medicines, but are forced to apply more desperate and more doubtful cures to more dangerous diseases.
tgt_text.548: It is the part of a madman to wish for an adverse tempest in a calm, but of a wise man to find relief against the tempest by what- ever means ;
tgt_text.549: and the rather if one incurs more advantage by accomplishing the matter than disadvantage by keeping it in suspense.
tgt_text.550: Now the conducting of enterprises is dangerous sometimes to the undertakers, and sometimes to the state;
tgt_text.551: and hence some are in danger of losing their lives, some their reputation, and some their popularity.
tgt_text.552: But we ought to be more forward to expose our own persons than the general interests to danger, and to be more ready to fight for honour and reputation than for other advantages.
tgt_text.553: Though many have been known cheerfully to venture not only their money but their lives for the public;
tgt_text.554: yet those very men have refused to suffer the smallest loss of glory even at the request of their country.
tgt_text.555: For instance, Calli- cratidas, who, after performing many gallant actions at the head of the Lacedemonian armies, during the Peloponesian war, at last threw everything into confusion by refusing to obey the directions of those who were for removing the fleet from Arginusæ, and not for fighting the Athenians ;
tgt_text.556: to whom his answer was, that if the Lacedemonians lost that fleet they could fit out another, but that he could not turn his back without dishonour to himself.
tgt_text.557: 'Tis true, the blow that followed upon this was not very severe to the Lacedemonians ;
tgt_text.558: but it was a deadly one, when, from a fear of public odium, Cleombrotus fought with Epamonidas, and the power of the Lacedemonians perished.
tgt_text.559: How preferable was the conduct of Quintus Maximus, of whom Ennius says :
tgt_text.560: — “ The man* who saved his country by delay, No tales could move him, and no envy sway;
tgt_text.561: And thus the laurels on his honoured brow, In age shall flourish, and with time shall grow."
tgt_text.562: This is a species of fault which ought also to be avoided in civil matters;
tgt_text.563: for there are some men who, from a dread of unpopularity, dare not express their opinions however excellent they may be.XXV.
tgt_text.564: All who hope to rise in a state ought strictly to observe two rules of Plato.
tgt_text.565: The first is, that they so keep in view the advantage of their fellow citizens as to have reference to it in whatever they do, regardless of their indi- vidual interest.*
tgt_text.566: The second is, that their cares be applied to the whole of the state, lest while they are cherishing one part they abandon the others.
tgt_text.567: For the administration of government, like a guardianship, ought to be directed to the good of those who confer, and not of those who receive the trust.
tgt_text.569: Now, they who consult the interests of one part of a community and neglect another, introduce into the state the greatest of all evils, sedition and discord.
tgt_text.570: From this partiality some seem to court the people, some each great man, but few the whole.
tgt_text.571: Hence the great discords amongst the Athenians, and in our government not only seditions but the most destructive wars, which every worthy and brave citizen who deserves to rise in the state will avoid and de- test :
tgt_text.572: he will give himself entirely up to the service of his country, without regard to riches or to power, and he will watch over the whole so as to consult the good of all, He will even be far from bringing any man into hatred or disgrace, by ill-grounded charges, and he will so closely attach himself to the rules of justice and virtue, that how- ever lie may give offence he will preserve them, and incur death itself rather than swerve from the principles I have laid down.
tgt_text.573: Of all evils, ambition and the disputes for public posts are the most deplorable.
tgt_text.574: Plato, likewise, on this subject, says very admirably, " that they who dispute for the management of a state resemble mariners wrangling about who should direct the helm."
tgt_text.575: He then lays down as a rule that we ought to look upon those as our enemies who take arms against the public, and not those who want to have public affairs directed by their judgment.
tgt_text.576: For instance, Publius Africanus and Quintus Metellus differed in opinion, but without animosity.
tgt_text.577: Nor, indeed, are those to be listened to who consider that we ought to cherish a bitter resentment against our enemies, and that this is characteristic of a high-minded and brave man;
tgt_text.578: for nothing is more noble, nothing more worthy of a great and a good man, than placability and moderation.*'
tgt_text.579: Nay, amidst free nations and equality of rights, an equability and loftiness of temper is necessary, to prevent our falling into an idle, disagreeable peevishness, when we are irritated by persons approaching us unseasonably, or preferring to us unreasonable requests.
tgt_text.580: Yet this politeness and moderation ought to be so tempered, that for the sake of the interests of the state severity should be employed, otherwise public business could not be carried on.
tgt_text.581: Meanwhile, all reprimands and punishments ought to be inflicted without abuse, without regard to the party so punishing or reprimanding, but to the good of the state.
tgt_text.582: We ought, likewise, to take care that the punishment be proportioned to the offence, * aDd that some be not punished for doing things for which others are not so much as called to account.
tgt_text.583: Above all things, in punishing we ought to guard against passion;
tgt_text.584: for the man who is to pronounce a sentence of punishment in a passion, never can preserve that mean between what is too much and too little, which is so justly recommended by the Peripatetics, did they not too much commend the passion of anger, by asserting it to be a useful property of our nature.
tgt_text.585: For my part, I think that it ought to be checked under all circumstances ;
tgt_text.586: † and it were to be wished that they who preside in government were like the laws, which in punishing are not directed by resentments but by equity.
tgt_text.588: Now, during our prosperity, and while things flow agreeably to our desire, we ought with great care to avoid pride and arrogance;
tgt_text.589: for, as it discovers weakness not to bear adversity with equanimity, so also with prosperity.
tgt_text.590: That equanimity in every condition of life is a noble attri- bute, and that uniform expression of countenance and appear- anc3 which we find recorded of Socrates, and also of Cams Lælius.
tgt_text.591: Though Philip of Macedon was excelled by his soil in his achievements and his renown, yet I find him superior to him in politeness and goodness of nature;
tgt_text.592: the one, there- fore, always appeared great, while the other often became detestable.
tgt_text.593: So that they appear to teach rightly, who admo- nish us that the more advanced we are in our fortune the more affable ought we to be in our behaviour.
tgt_text.594: Panætius tells us his scholar and friend, Africanus, used to say, that as horses, grown unruly by being in frequent engagements, are delivered over to be tamed by horse-breakers, thus men, who grow riotous and self-sufficient by prosperity, ought, as it were, to be exercised in the traverse of reason and phi- losophy, that they may learn the inconstancy of human affairs and the uncertainty of fortune.
tgt_text.595: In the time of our greatest prosperity we should also have the greatest recourse to the advice of our friends, and greater authority should be conceded to them than before.
tgt_text.596: At such a time we are to take care not to lend our ears to flatterers, or to suffer ourselves to be imposed upon by adulation, by which it is easy to be misled:
tgt_text.597: for we then think ourselves such as may be justly praised, an opinion that gives rise to a thousand errors in conduct;
tgt_text.598: because, when men are once blown up with idle conceits, they are exposed to igno- minious ridicule and led into the greatest mistakes.
tgt_text.600: One thing you are to understand, that they who regulate public affairs perform the greatest exploits, and such as require the highest style of mind, because their business is most extensive and concerns the greatest number.
tgt_text.601: Yet there are, and have been, many men of great capacities, who in private life have planned out or attempted mighty matters, and yet have confined themselves to the limits of their own affairs;
tgt_text.602: or, being thrown into a middle state, between phi losophers and those who govern the state, have amused themselves with the management of their private fortune, without swelling it by all manner of means, not debarring their friends from the benefit of it, but rather, when occasion calls upon them, sharing it both with their friends and their country.
tgt_text.603: This should be originally acquired with honesty, without any scandalous or oppressive practices;
tgt_text.604: it should then be made serviceable to as many as possible, provided they be worthy;
tgt_text.605: it should next be augmented by prudence, by industry, and frugality, without serving the purposes of pleasure and luxury rather than of generosity and humanity.
tgt_text.606: The man who observes those rules may live with magni- ficence, with dignity, and with spirit, yet with simplicity and honour, and agreeably to (the economy of) human life.
tgt_text.608: The next thing is, to treat of that remaining part of virtue in which consist chastity and those (as we may term them) ornaments of life, temperance, moderation, and all that allays the perturbations of the mind.
tgt_text.609: Under this head is comprehended what in Latin we may call decorum (or the graceful), for the Greeks term it the πϱεπον.
tgt_text.610: Now, its quality is such that it is indiscernible from the honestum ;
tgt_text.611: for what- ever is graceful is virtuous, and whatever is virtuous is graceful.
tgt_text.612: But it is more easy to conceive than to express the differ- ence between what is virtuous and what is graceful (or between the honestum and the decorum;
tgt_text.613: ) for whatever is graceful appears such, when virtue is its antecedent.
tgt_text.614: What is graceful, therefore, appears not only in that division of virtue which is here treated of, but in the three foregoing ones ;
tgt_text.615: for it is graceful in a man to think and to speak with propriety, to act with deliberation, and in every occurrence of life to find out and persevere in the truth.
tgt_text.616: On the other hand, to be imposed upon, to mistake, to faulter, and to be deceived, is as ungraceful as to rave or to be insane.
tgt_text.617: Thus, whatever is just is graceful;
tgt_text.618: whatever is unjust is as un- graceful as it is criminal.
tgt_text.619: The same principle applies to courage;
tgt_text.620: for every manly and magnanimous action is worthy of a man and graceful;
tgt_text.621: the reverse, as being unworthy, is ungraceful.
tgt_text.622: This, therefore, which I call gracefulness, is a universal property of virtue, and a property that is self-evident, and not discerned by any profundity of reasoning;
tgt_text.623: for there is a certain gracefulness that is implied in every virtue, and which may exist distinctly from virtue, rather in thought than in fact:
tgt_text.624: as grace and beauty of person, for example, cannot be separated from health, so the whole of that grace- fulness which I here speak of is blended with virtue, but may exist separately in the mind and in idea.
tgt_text.625: Now, the definition of this is twofold :
tgt_text.626: for there is a general gracefulness that is the property of all virtue, and that in- eludes another, which is fitted to the particular divisions of virtue.
tgt_text.627: The former is commonly defined to be that grace- fulness that is conformable to that excellence of man, in which he differs from other sentient beings;
tgt_text.628: but the special, which is comprised under the general, is defined to be a gracefulness so adapted to nature as to exhibit propriety and sweetness under a certain elegant appearance.
tgt_text.630: We may perceive that these things are so understood from that gracefulness which is aimed at by the poets, and of which elsewhere more is wont to be said ;
tgt_text.631: for we say that the poets observe that gracefulness to be when a person speaks and acts in that manner which is most becoming his character.
tgt_text.632: Thus if Æacus or Minos should say:
tgt_text.633: -Let them hate me, so they fear me ;
tgt_text.634: Or-The father's belly is his children's grave,it would seem unsuitable, because we know them to have been just persons;
tgt_text.635: but when said by an Atreus, they are received with applause, because the speech is worthy of the character.
tgt_text.636: Now, poets will form their judgment of what is becoming in each individual according to his character;
tgt_text.637: but nature herself has stamped on us a character in excellence greatly surpassing the rest of the animal creation.
tgt_text.638: Poets, therefore, in their vast variety of characters, con- sider what is proper and what is becoming, even in the vicious:
tgt_text.639: but as nature herself has cast to us our parts in constancy moderation, temperance, and modesty;
tgt_text.640: as she, at the same time, instructs us not to be unmindful, how we should behave to mankind, the effect is, that the extent both of that gracefulness which is the general property of all virtue, and of that particular gracefulness that is adapted to every species of it, is discovered.
tgt_text.641: For as personal beauty, by the sym- metrical disposition of the limbs, attracts our attention and pleases the eye, by the harmony and elegance with which each part corresponds to another, so that gracefulness which manifests itself in life, attracts the approbation of those among whom we live, by the order, consistency, and modesty of all our words and deeds.
tgt_text.642: There is, therefore, a degree of respect due from us, suited to every man's character, from the best to the worst:
tgt_text.643: for it it is not only arrogant, but it is profligate, for a man to disre- gard the world's opinion of himself;
tgt_text.644: but, in our estimate of human life, we are to make a difference between justice and moral susceptibility.*
tgt_text.645: The dictate of justice is to do no wrong;
tgt_text.646: that of moral susceptibility is to give no offence to mankind, and in this the force of the graceful is most per- ceptible.
tgt_text.647: By these explanations I conceive that what we mean by the graceful and becoming may be understood.
tgt_text.648: Now the duty resulting from this has a primary tendency to an agreement with and conservation of our nature ;
tgt_text.649: and if we follow it as a guide we never shall err, but shall attain to that natural excellence which consists in acuteness and sagacity, to that which is best adapted to human society, and to that which is energetic and manly.*
tgt_text.650: But the chief force of the graceful lies in that suitableness of which I am now treating.
tgt_text.651: For not only those emotions of a physical kind, but still more those of the mind are to be approved as they are conformable to nature.
tgt_text.652: For the nature and powers of the mind are two-fold ;
tgt_text.653: one consists in appetite, by the Greeks called (i. e. impulse) which hurries man hither and thither ;
tgt_text.654: the other in reason, which teaches and explains what we are to do, and what we are to avoid.
tgt_text.655: The result is, that reason should direct and appetite obey.
tgt_text.657: Now every human action ought to be free from precipitancy and negligence, nor indeed ought we to do anything for which we cannot give a justifiable reason.
tgt_text.658: This indeed almost amounts to a definition of duty.
tgt_text.659: Now we must manage so as to keep the appetites subservient to reason, that they may neither outstrip it, nor fall behind through sloth and cowardice.
tgt_text.660: Let them be ever composed and free from all perturbation of spirit;
tgt_text.661: and thus entire consistency and moderation will display themselves.
tgt_text.662: For those appetites that are too vagrant and rampant as it were, either through desire or aversion, are not sufficiently under the command of reason ;
tgt_text.663: such, 1 say, undoubtedly transgress bounds and moderation.
tgt_text.664: For they abandon and disclaim that subordination to reason, to which by the law of nature they are subjected, and thereby not only the mind but the body is thrown into disturbance.
tgt_text.665: Let any one observe the very looks of men who are in a rage, of those who are.
tgt_text.666: agitated by desire or fear, or who exult in an excess of joy ;
tgt_text.667: all whose countenances, voices, motions, and attitudes, are changed.
tgt_text.668: But to return to my description of duty.
tgt_text.669: From these par- ticulars we learn that all our appetites ought to be contracted and mitigated ;
tgt_text.670: that all our attention and diligence ought to be awake, so that we do nothing in a rash, random, thought- less, and inconsiderate manner.
tgt_text.671: For nature has not formed us to sport and merriment, but rather to seriousness, and studies that are important and sublime.
tgt_text.672: Sport and merriment are not always disallowable :
tgt_text.673: but we are to use them as we do sleep and other kinds of repose, when we have despatched our weighty and important affairs.
tgt_text.674: Nay, our very manner of joking should be neither wanton nor indecent, but genteel and good-humoured.
tgt_text.675: For as we indulge boys not in an unlimited licence of sport, but only in that which is not inconsistent with virtuous conduct, so in our very jokes there should appear some gleam of a virtuous nature.
tgt_text.676: The manner of joking is reduceable under two denomina- tions ;
tgt_text.677: -one that is ill-bred, insolent, profligate, and obscene ;
tgt_text.678: another that is elegant, polite, witty, and good-humoured.
tgt_text.679: We have abundance of this last, not only in our Plautus, and the authors of the old Greek comedy, but in the writings of the Socratic philosophers.
tgt_text.680: Many collections have likewise been made by various writers, of humorous sayings, such as that made by Cato, and called his Apopthegms.
tgt_text.681: The dis- tinction, therefore, between a genteel and an ill-mannered joke is a very ready one.
tgt_text.682: The former, if seasonably made, and when the attention is relaxed, is worthy of a virtuous man ;
tgt_text.683: the other, if it exhibit immorality in its subject, or obscenity in the expression, is unworthy even of a man.
tgt_text.684: There is likewise a certain limit to be observed, even in our amusements, that we do not give up everything to amusement, and that, after being elevated by pleasure, we do not sink into some immorality.
tgt_text.685: Our Campus Martins, and the sport of hunting, supply creditable examples of amusement.
tgt_text.687: But in all our disquisitions concerning the nature of a duty, it is material that we keep in our eye the great excellence of man's nature above that of the brutes and all other creatures.
tgt_text.688: They are insensible to everything but pleasure, and are hurried to it by every impulse.
tgt_text.689: Whereas the mind of man is nourished by study and reflection, and, being charmed by the pleasure of seeing and hearing, it is ever either inquiring or acting.
tgt_text.690: But if there is a man who has a small bias to pleasure, provided he is not of the brute kind (for there are some who are men only in name) ;
tgt_text.691: but, I say, if he is more high-minded even in a small degree, though he may be smitten with pleasure, he yet, through a principle of shame, hides and disguises his inclination for it.
tgt_text.692: From this we are to conclude that mere corporeal pleasure is unworthy the excellency of man's nature ;
tgt_text.693: and that it ought therefore to be despised and rejected ;
tgt_text.694: but that if a man shall have any delight in pleasure, he ought to be extremely observant of limits in its indulgence.
tgt_text.695: Therefore, the nourish- ment and dress of our bodies should be with a view not to our pleasure, but to our health and our strength ;
tgt_text.696: and should we examine the excellency and dignity of our nature, we should then be made sensible how shameful it is to melt away in pleasure, and to live in voluptuousness and effemi- nacy ;
tgt_text.697: and how noble it is to live with abstinence, with modesty, with strictness, and sobriety.
tgt_text.698: We are likewise to observe, that nature has, as it were, endowed us with two characters.
tgt_text.699: The first is in common to all mankind, because all of its partake in that excellency of reason, which places us above the brutes ;
tgt_text.700: from which is derived all that is virtuous, all that is graceful, and by which we trace our connections with our several duties.
tgt_text.701: The other character is peculiar to individuals.
tgt_text.702: For, as there are great dissimilarities in our persons-some for instance are swift in running, others strong in wrestling ;
tgt_text.703: and in style of beauty some have a dignity, and others a sweetness of aspect-so are there still greater varieties in our minds.
tgt_text.704: Lucius Crassus and Lucius Philippus had a great deal of wit;
tgt_text.705: but in Caius Cæsar, the son of Lucius, it was greater in degree, and more elaborate.
tgt_text.706: In their contemporaries, Marcus Scaurus, and young Mareus Drusus, there was a remarkable seriousness ;
tgt_text.708: but in his friend Scipio greater ambition, and a graver style of life.
tgt_text.709: As to the Greeks, we are told of Socrates that he was agreeable and witty ;
tgt_text.710: his conversation jocose, and in all his discourse a feigner of opinions whom the Greeks called ε’ίϱων.
tgt_text.711: On the other hand, Pythagoras and Pericles, without any gaiety, attained the highest authority.
tgt_text.712: Amongst the Carthaginian generals, Hannibal, we learn, was crafty, and Quintus Maximus amongst our own generals was apt at con- cealment, secrecy, dissimulation, plotting, and anticipating the designs of enemies.
tgt_text.713: In this class the Greeks rank Themis- tocles, and lason of Pheræ, above all others ;
tgt_text.714: and place among the very first, that cunning and artful device of Solon, when, to secure his own life, and that he might be of greater service to his country, he counterfeited madness.
tgt_text.715: In opposition to those characters, the tempers of many others are plain and open.
tgt_text.716: Lovers of truth and haters of deceit, they think that nothing should be done by stealth, nothing by stratagem ;
tgt_text.717: while others care not what they suffer themselves, or whom they stoop to, provided they accomplish their ends;
tgt_text.718: as we have seen Sylla and Marcus Crassus.
tgt_text.719: In which class Lysander the Lacedemonian, we are told, had the greatest art and per- severance, and that Callicratides, who succeeded to Lysander in the command of the fleet, was the reverse.
tgt_text.720: We have known some others, who though very powerful in conversation, always make themselves appear undistinguished individuals among many ;
tgt_text.721: such were the Catuli, father and son, and Quintus Mucius Mancia.
tgt_text.722: I have heard from men older than myself, that Publius Scipio Nasica was of the same cast, but that his father, the same who punished the pernicious designs of Tiberius Gracchus, was void of all politeness in conver- sation :
tgt_text.723: and the same of Xenocrates, the most austere of philosophers, and from that very circumstance a distinguished and celebrated man.
tgt_text.724: Innumerable, but far from being blame- able, are the other differences in the natures and manners of men.XXXI.
tgt_text.725: Every man, however, ought carefully to follow out his peculiar character, provided it is only peculiar, and not vicious, that he may the more easily attain that grace- fulness of which we are inquiring.
tgt_text.726: For we ought to manage so as never to counteract the general system of nature;
tgt_text.727: but having taken care of that, we are to follow our natural bias;
tgt_text.728: insomuch, that though other studies may be of greater weight and excellence, yet we are to regulate our pursuits by the disposition of our nature.
tgt_text.729: It is to no purpose to thwart nature, or to aim at what you cannot attain.
tgt_text.730: We therefore may have a still clearer conception of the graceful I am recommending, from this consideration, that nothing is grace- ful that goes (as the saying is) against the grain, that is, in contradiction and opposition to nature.
tgt_text.731: If anything at all is graceful, nothing surely is more so than a uniformity through the course of all your life, as well as through every particular action of it ;
tgt_text.732: and you never can preserve this uniformity, if, aping another man's nature, you forsake your own.
tgt_text.733: For as we ought to converse in the language we are best acquainted with, for fear of making ourselves justly ridiculous, as those do who cram in Greek expressions ;
tgt_text.734: so there ought to be no incongruity in our actions, and none in all the tenor of our lives.
tgt_text.735: *Now so powerful is this difference of natures, that it may be the duty of one man to put himself to death, and yet not of another, though in the same predicament.
tgt_text.736: For was the predicament of Marcus Cato different from that of those who surrendered themselves to Cæsar in Africa?
tgt_text.737: Yet it had been perhaps blameable in the latter, had they put them- selves to death, because their lives were less severe, and their moral natures more pliable.
tgt_text.738: But it became Cato, who had by perpetual perseverance strengthened that inflexibility which nature had given him, and had never departed from the purpose and resolution lie had once formed, to die rather than to look upon the face of a tyrant.†
tgt_text.739: How various were those sufferings of Ulysses, in his long continued wanderings, when he became the slave of women (if you consider Circe and Calypso as such):
tgt_text.740: and in all he said he sought to be complaisant and agreeable to every body, nay, put up with abuses from slaves and handmaidens at home, that he might at length compass what he desired;
tgt_text.741: but with the spirit with which he is represented, Ajax would have preferred a thousand deaths to suffering such indig- nities.
tgt_text.742: In the contemplation of which each ought to consider what is peculiar to himself, and to regulate those peculiari- ties, without making any experiments how another man's become them;
tgt_text.743: for that manner which is most peculiarly a man's own always becomes him best.
tgt_text.744: Every man ought, therefore, to study his own genius, so as to become an impartial judge of his own good and bad qualities, otherwise the players will discover better sense than we;
tgt_text.745: for they don't choose for themselves those parts that are the most excellent, but those which are best adapted to them.
tgt_text.746: Those who rely on their voices choose the part of Epigonas or Medus ;
tgt_text.747: the best actors that of Menalippa or Clytemnestra.
tgt_text.748: Rupilius, who I remember, always selected that of Antiopa;
tgt_text.749: Esopus seldom chose that of Ajax.
tgt_text.750: Shall a player, then, observe this upon the stage, and shall a wise man not observe it in the conduct of life ?
tgt_text.751: Let us, there- fore, most earnestly apply to those parts for which we are best fitted;
tgt_text.752: but should necessity degrade us into characters unsuitable to our genius, let us employ all our care, attention, and industry, in endeavouring to perform them, if not with propriety, with as little impropriety as possible:
tgt_text.753: nor should we strive so much to attain excellencies which have not been conferred on us, as to avoid defects.
tgt_text.755: To the two characters above described is added a third, which either accident or occasion imposes on us;
tgt_text.756: and even a fourth, which we accommodate to ourselves by our own judgment and choice.
tgt_text.757: Now kingdoms, governments, honours, dignities, riches, interest, and whatever are the qualities contrary to them, happen through accident, and are directed by occasions;
tgt_text.758: but what part we ourselves should wish to act, originates from our own will.
tgt_text.759: Some, therefore, apply to philosophy, some to the civil law, and some to elo- quence ;
tgt_text.760: and of the virtues themselves some endeavour to shine in one, and some in another.
tgt_text.761: Men generally are ambitious of distinguishing themselves in that kind of excellence in which their fathers or their an- cestors were most famous:
tgt_text.762: for instance, Quintus, the son of Publius Mucius, in the civil law;
tgt_text.763: Africanus, the son of Paulus, in the art of war.
tgt_text.764: Some, however, increase, by merits of their own, that glory which they have received from their fathers;
tgt_text.765: for the same Africanus crowned his military glory with the practice of eloquence.
tgt_text.766: In like manner, Timo- theus, the son of Conon, who equalled his father in the duties of the field, but added to them the glory of genius and learning.
tgt_text.767: Sometimes, however, it happens that men, laying aside the imitation of their ancestors, follow a purpose of their own;
tgt_text.768: and this is most commonly the case with such men who, though descended from obscure ancestors, purpose to them- selves great aims.
tgt_text.769: In our search, then, after what is graceful, all those parti- culars ought to be embraced in our contemplation and study.
tgt_text.770: In the first place, we are to determine who and what manner of men we are to be, and what mode of life we are to adopt- a consideration which is the most difficult of all;
tgt_text.771: for, in our early youth, when there is the greatest weakness of judgment, every one chooses to himself that kind of life which he has most fancied.
tgt_text.772: He, therefore, is trepanned into some fixed and settled course of living before lie is capable to judge what is the most proper.
tgt_text.773: *For the Hercules of Prodicus, as we learn from Xenophon, in his early puberty (an age appointed by nature for every man's choosing his scheme of life) is said to have gone into a solitude, and there sitting down, to have deliberated within himself much, and for a long time, whether of two paths that he saw before him it was better to enter on, the one of pleasure, the other of virtue.
tgt_text.774: This might, indeed, happen to a Jove- begotten Hercules;
tgt_text.775: but not so with us, who imitate those whom we have an opinion of, and are thereby drawn into their pursuits and purposes:
tgt_text.776: for generally, prepossessed by the principles of our parents, we are drawn away to their customs and habits.
tgt_text.777: Others, swayed by the judgment of the multitude, are passionately fond of those things which seem best to the majority.
tgt_text.778: A few, however, either through some good fortune, or a certain excellency of nature, or through the training of their parents, pursue the right path of life.
tgt_text.780: The rarest class is composed of those who, endowed with an exalted genius, or with excellent educa- tion and learning, or possessing both, have had scope enough for deliberating as to what course of life they would be most willing to adopt.
tgt_text.781: Every design, in such a delibera- tion, ought to be referred to the natural powers of the indi- vidual;
tgt_text.782: for since, as I said before, we discover this propriety in every act which is performed, by reference to the qualities with which a man is born, so, in fixing the plan of our future life, we ought to be still much more careful in that respect, that we may be consistent throughout the duration of life with ourselves, and not deficient in any one duty.
tgt_text.783: But because nature in this possesses the chief power, and fortune the next, we ought to pay regard to both in fixing our scheme of life;
tgt_text.784: but chiefly to nature, as she is much more firm and constant, insomuch that the struggle, some- times between nature and fortune, seems to be between a mortal and an immortal being.
tgt_text.785: The mail, therefore, who adapts his whole system of living to his undepraved nature, let him maintain his constancy;
tgt_text.786: for that, above all things, becomes a man, provided he come not to learn that he has been mistaken in his choice of a mode of life.
tgt_text.787: Should that occur, as it possibly may, a change must be made in all his habits and purposes which, if circumstances shall be favourable, we shall more easily and readily effect;
tgt_text.788: but, should it happen otherwise, it must be done slowly and gradually.
tgt_text.789: Thus, men of sense think it more suitable that friendships which are disagreeable or not approved should be gradually detached, rather than suddenly cut off.
tgt_text.790: Still, upon altering our scheme of life, we ought to take the utmost care to make it appear that we have done it upon good grounds.
tgt_text.791: But if, as I said above, we are to imitate our ancestors, this should be first excepted that their bad qualities must not be imitated.
tgt_text.792: In the next place, if nature does not qualify us to imitate them in some things, we are not to attempt it:
tgt_text.793: for instance, the son of the elder African us, who adopted the younger son of Paulus, could not, from infirmity of health, resemble his father so much as his father did his grand- father.
tgt_text.794: If, therefore, a man is unable to defend causes, to entertain the people by haranguing, or to wage war, yet still he ought to do what is in his power;
tgt_text.795: he ought to practise justice, honour, generosity, modesty, and temperance, that what is wanting may be the less required of him.
tgt_text.796: Now, the best inheritance a parent can leave a child--more excellent than any patrimony-is the glory of his virtue and his deeds;
tgt_text.797: to bring disgrace on which ought to be regarded as wicked and monstrous.
tgt_text.799: And as the same moral duties are not suited to the different periods of life, some belonging to the young, others to the old, we must likewise say somewhat on this distinc- tion.
tgt_text.800: It is the duty of a young man to reverence his elders, and amongst them to select the best and the worthiest, on whose advice and authority to rely.
tgt_text.801: For the inexperience of youth ought to be instructed and conducted by the wisdom of the aged.
tgt_text.802: Above all things, the young man ought to be restrained from lawless desires, and exercised in endurance and labour both of body and mind, that by persevering in them, he may be efficient in the duties both of war and peace.
tgt_text.803: Nay, when they even unbend their minds and give them- selves up to mirth, they ought to avoide intemperance, and never lose sight of morality ;
tgt_text.804: and this will be the more easy if even upon such occasions they desire that their elders should be associated with them.
tgt_text.805: *As to old men, their bodily labours seem to require diminu- tion, but the exercises of their mind ought even to be increased.
tgt_text.806: Their care should be to assist their friends, the youth, and above all their country, to the utmost of their ability by their advice and experience.
tgt_text.807: Now there is nothing that old age ought more carefully to guard against, than giving itself up to listlessness and indolence.
tgt_text.808: As to luxury, though it is shameful in every stage of life, in old age it is detestable ;
tgt_text.809: but if to that is added intemperance in lawless desires, the evil is doubled;
tgt_text.810: because old age itself thereby incurs dis- grace ;

tgt_text.1014: Of all virtues, the most leading is that wisdom which the Greeks call σοϕια, for by that sagacity which they term ϕρονησις we understand quite another thing, as it implies the knowledge of what things are to be de- sired, and what to be avoided.

tgt_text.1018: now activity is most perspi- cuous when it is exerted in protecting the rights of mankind.
tgt_text.1019: It therefore has reference to the social interests of the human race, and is for that reason preferable to knowledge;

tgt_text.1034: It is therefore more serviceable to the public for a man to discourse copiously, provided it is to the purpose, than for a man to think ever so accurately without the power of expression ;

tgt_text.1036: Now as the swarms of bees do not assemble in order to form the honey-comb, but form the honey-comb because they are by nature gregarious ;

tgt_text.1133: And certainly there could have been no exportation of things in which we abound, and importation of those which we want, had not mankind applied themselves to those employments.
tgt_text.1134: In like manner, neither could stones be hewn for our use, nor iron, nor brass, nor gold, nor silver, be dug from the earth, but by the toil and art of man.

tgt_text.1271: but next to that, good-will is won by a beneficent disposition, though we may be desti- tute of means.
tgt_text.1272: Thirdly, the affections of the public are wonderfully excited by the mere reputation of generosity, beneficence, justice, honour, and of all those virtues that re- gard politeness and affability of manners.
tgt_text.1273: For the very honestum and the graceful, as it is called, because it charms us by its own properties, and touches the hearts of all by its qualities and its beauties, is chiefly resplendent through the medium of those virtues I have mentioned.
tgt_text.1274: We are there- fore drawn, as it were, by nature herself to the love of those in whom we think those virtues reside.
tgt_text.1275: Now these are the strongest causes of affection, though some there may be which are less material.
tgt_text.1276: The acquisition of public confidence or trust may be effected by two considerations;
tgt_text.1277: by being supposed to be pos- sessed of wisdom and of justice combined.
tgt_text.1278: For we have confidence in those who we think understand more than our- selves, and who we believe see further into the future, and, when business is actually in hand and matters come to trial, know how to pursue the wisest measures and act in the most expedient manner, as the exigency may require;
tgt_text.1279: all mankind agreeing that this is real and useful wisdom.
tgt_text.1280: Such confidence, also, is placed in honest and honourable men, that is, in good men, as to exclude all suspicion of fraud or injury.
tgt_text.1281: We therefore think we act safely and properly in entrusting them with our persons, our fortunes, and our families.
tgt_text.1282: But of the two virtues, honesty and wisdom, the former is the most powerful in winning the confidence of mankind.
tgt_text.1283: For honesty without wisdom, has influence sufficient of it- self ;
tgt_text.1284: but wisdom without honesty is of no effect in inspiring confidence;
tgt_text.1285: because, when we have no opinion of a man's probity, the greater his craft and cunning, the more hated and suspected he becomes;
tgt_text.1286: honesty, therefore, joined to un- derstanding, will have unbounded power in acquiring con- fidence ;
tgt_text.1287: honesty without understanding can do a great deal;
tgt_text.1288: but understanding without honesty can do nothing.
tgt_text.1290: But lest any one should wonder why, as all philosophers are agreed in one maxim, which I myself have often main- tained, that the man who possesses one of the virtues is in possession of them all, I here make a distinction which im- plies that a man may be just but not at the same time pru- dent, there is one kind of accuracy which in disputation refines even upon truth, and another kind, when our whole discourse is accommodated to the understanding of the public.
tgt_text.1291: Therefore I here make use of the common terms of discourse, by calling some men brave, some good, others prudent.
tgt_text.1292: For when we treat of popular opinions, we should make use of popular terms, and Panætius did the same.
tgt_text.1293: But to return to our subject.
tgt_text.1294: Of the three requisites of perfect popularity, the third I mentioned was, " when the public with a certain degree of admiration judges us to be worthy of preferment."
tgt_text.1295: Now everything that men observe to be great and above their comprehension they commonly admire ;
tgt_text.1296: and with regard to individuals, those in whom they can see any unexpected excellences.
tgt_text.1297: They therefore behold with reverence and extol with the greatest praise, those men in whom they think they can perceive some distinguished or singular vir- tues ;
tgt_text.1298: whereas they despise those whom they think to possess no virtue, spirit, or manliness.
tgt_text.1299: Now, men do not despise all those of whom they think ill.
tgt_text.1300: For they by no means con- temn rogues, slanderers, cheats, and those who are prepared to commit an injury, though they have a bad opinion of them.
tgt_text.1301: Therefore, as I have already said, those are despised who can neither serve themselves nor any one else, who have no assiduity, no industry, and no concern about them;
tgt_text.1302: but those men are the objects of admiration who are thought to surpass others in virtue, and to be free as well from every disgrace, as especially from those vices which others cannot easily resist.
tgt_text.1303: For pleasures, those most charming mistresses, turn aside the greater number of minds from virtue, and most men, when the fires of affliction are applied to them, are un- measurably terrified.
tgt_text.1304: Life and death, poverty and riches, make the deepest impressions upon all men.
tgt_text.1305: But as to those who, with a great and elevated mind, look down on these in- differently;
tgt_text.1306: -men whom a lofty and noble object, when it is presented to them, draws and absorbs to itself;
tgt_text.1307: -in such cases, who does not admire the splendour and the beauty of virtue ?
tgt_text.1309: This sublimity of soul, therefore, produces the highest admiration ;
tgt_text.1310: and above all justice, from which single virtue men are called good, appears to the multitude as something marvellous.
tgt_text.1312: for no man can be just if he is afraid of death, pain, exile, or poverty, or prefers their contraries to justice.
tgt_text.1313: Men especially admire him who is incorruptible by money, and they consider every man in whom that quality is seen as ore purified by the fire.
tgt_text.1314: Justice, therefore, comprehends all the three means of acquir- in- glory which have been laid down.
tgt_text.1315: The love of the pub- lie, on account of its being a general benefit;
tgt_text.1316: its confidence, for the same reason ;
tgt_text.1317: and its admiration, because it neglects and despises those objects to which most men are hurried on inflamed with avidity.
tgt_text.1318: In my opinion, however, every scheme and purpose of life requires the assistance of men, especially that one should have some with whom he can familiarly unbosom himself, which is hard for one to do, unless he maintain the appear- ance of a good man.
tgt_text.1319: For this reason, were a man to live ever so lonely or ever so retired in the country, a reputation for justice would be indispensable to him, and so much the more, as those who do not possess it will be esteemed dis- honest, and thus surrounded by no protection will be ex- posed to numerous injuries.
tgt_text.1320: And with those likewise who buy or sell, who hire or let out, or who are engaged in the transaction of business, justice is necessary to the carrying of their pursuits, for its influ- ence is so great, that without some grains of it, even they who live by malpractices and villiany could not subsist.
tgt_text.1321: For amongst those who thieve in company, if any one of them cheat or rob another he is turned out of the gang;
tgt_text.1322: and the captain of the band himself, unless he should distribute the spoils impartially, would either be murdered or deserted by his fellows.
tgt_text.1323: Indeed, robbers are even said to have their laws, which they obey and observe.
tgt_text.1324: By this impartiality in sharing the booty, Bardyllis, the Illyrian robber, mentioned by Theopompus, obtained great wealth;
tgt_text.1325: and Viriathus, the Lusitanian, much greater;
tgt_text.1326: to whom our armies and our gene- rals yielded ;
tgt_text.1327: but whom the prætor Caius Lælius, surnamed the wise, crushed and subdued, and so repressed his ferocity that he left an easy victory to his successors.
tgt_text.1328: If, therefore, the influence of justice is so forcible as to strengthen and enlarge the power of robbers, how great must we suppose it to be amidst the laws and administration of a well-consti- tuted government ?XII.
tgt_text.1329: It appears to me, that not only among the Medes, as we are told by Herodotus, but by our own ancestors, men of the best principles were constituted kings, for the benefit of their just government.
tgt_text.1330: For when the helpless people were oppressed by those who had greater power, they betook themselves to some one man who was distinguished by his virtue, who not only protected the weakest from oppression, but by setting up an equitable system of government, united highest and lowest in equal rights.
tgt_text.1331: The cause of the institu- tion of laws was the same as that of kings;
tgt_text.1332: for equality of rights has ever been the object of desire;
tgt_text.1333: nor otherwise can there be any rights at all.
tgt_text.1334: When mankind could enjoy it under one just and good man, they were satisfied with that;
tgt_text.1335: but when that was not the case, laws were invented, which perpetually spoke to all men with one and the same voice.
tgt_text.1336: It is therefore undeniable that the men whose reputation among the people was the highest for their justice, were commonly chosen to bear rule.
tgt_text.1337: But when the same were likewise regarded as wise men, there was nothing the people did not think themselves capa- ble of attaining under such authority.
tgt_text.1338: Justice, therefore, is by all manner of means to be reverenced and practised ;
tgt_text.1339: both for its own sake (for otherwise it would not be justice), and for the enlargement of our own dignity and popularity.
tgt_text.1340: But as there is a system not only for the acquisition of money but also for its investment, so that it may supply ever- recurring expenses, not only the needful but the liberal;
tgt_text.1341: so popularity must be both acquired and maintained by system.
tgt_text.1342: It was finely said by Socrates that the shortest and most direct road to popularity, is "for a man to be the same that he wishes to be taken for."
tgt_text.1343: People are egregiously mistaken if they think they ever can attain to permanent popularity by hypocrisy, by mere outside appearances, and by disguising not only their language but their looks.
tgt_text.1344: True popularity takes deep root and spreads itself wide;
tgt_text.1345: but the false falls away like blossoms;
tgt_text.1346: for nothing that is false can be lasting.
tgt_text.1347: I could bring many instances of both kinds;
tgt_text.1348: but for the sake of liberty, I will confine myself to one family.
tgt_text.1349: While there is a memorial of Roman history remaining, the memory cf Tiberius Gracchus, the son of Publius, will be held in honour;
tgt_text.1350: but his sons even in life were not approved of by the good, and, being dead, they are ranked amongst those who were deservedly put to death.
tgt_text.1352: Let the man therefore who aspires after true popula- rity, perform the duties of justice.
tgt_text.1353: What these are has been laid down in the former book.
tgt_text.1354: But although we may most easily seem to be just what we are (though in this of itself there is very great importance), yet some precepts require to be given as to how we may be such men as we desire to be considered.
tgt_text.1355: For if any one from early youth has the elements of celebrity and reputation, either derived from his father (which I fancy, my dear Cicero, has happened to you), or by some other cause or accident;
tgt_text.1356: the eyes of all mankind are turned towards him, and they make it their business to inquire what he does and how he lives;
tgt_text.1357: and, as if he were set up in the strongest point of light, no word or deed of his can be private.
tgt_text.1358: Now those whose early life, through their mean and ob- scure rank, is passed unnoticed by the public, when they come to be young men, ought to contemplate important pur- poses.
tgt_text.1359: and pursue them by the most direct means, which they will do with a firmer resolution, because not only is no envy felt.
tgt_text.1360: but favour rather is shown towards that period of life.
tgt_text.1361: The chief recommendation then of a young man to fame is derived from military exploits.*
tgt_text.1362: Of this we have many ex- amples amongst our ancestors, for they were almost always waging wars.
tgt_text.1363: Your youth however has fallen upon the time cf a war, in which one party incurred too much guilt and to- other too little success.
tgt_text.1364: But when in that war Pompey gave you the command of a squadron, you gained the praise of that great man and of his army by your horsemanship, your darting the javelin, and your tolerance of all military labour.
tgt_text.1365: But this honour of yours ceased with the constitution of our country.
tgt_text.1366: My discourse however has not been undertaken with reference to you singly, but to the general subject.
tgt_text.1367: Let me therefore proceed to what remains.
tgt_text.1368: As in other matters the powers of the mind are far more important than those of the body, so the objects we pursue by intelligence and reason are more important than those we effeet by bodily strength.
tgt_text.1369: The most early recommendation, therefore, is modesty, obedience to parents, and affection for relations.
tgt_text.1370: Young men are likewise most easily and best known, who attach themselves to wise and illustrious men who benefit their country by their counsels.
tgt_text.1371: Their frequent- ing such company gives mankind a notion of their one day resembling those whom they choose for imitation.
tgt_text.1372: The frequenting of the house of Publius Marcus com- mended the early life of Publius Rutilius to a reputation for integrity and knowledge of the law.
tgt_text.1373: Lueius Crassus indeed, when very young, was indebted to no extrinsic source, but by himself acquired the highest honour from that noble and celebrated prosecution he undertook;
tgt_text.1374: and at an age when even those who exercise themselves are highly applauded (as we are told in the case of Demosthenes), Crassus, I say, at that age showed that he could already do that most success- fully in the forum, which at that time he would have gained praise had he attempted at home.
tgt_text.1376: But as there are two methods of speaking;
tgt_text.1377: the one proper for conversation, the other for debate;
tgt_text.1378: there can be no doubt but the disputative style of speech is of the greatest efficacy with regard to fame ;
tgt_text.1379: for that is what we properly term eloquence.
tgt_text.1380: Yet it is difficult to describe how great power, affability and politeness in conversation have to win the affections of mankind.
tgt_text.1381: There are extant letters from Philip, from Antipater, and from Anti-onus, three of the wisest men we meet with in history, to their sons Alexander, Cas- sander, and Philip, recommending to them to draw the minds of the people to kindly sentiments by a generous style of discourse, and to engage their soldiers by a winning address.
tgt_text.1382: But the speech which is pronounced in debate before a mul- titude often carries away a whole assembly.
tgt_text.1383: For great is their admiration of an eloquent and sensible speaker, that when they hear him, they are convinced he has both greater abilities and more wisdom than the rest of mankind.
tgt_text.1384: But should this eloquence have in it dignity combined with mo- desty, nothing can be more admirable, especially should those properties meet in a young man.
tgt_text.1385: Various are the causes that require the practice of elo- quence ;
tgt_text.1386: and many young men in our state have attained distinction before the judges and in the senate ;
tgt_text.1387: but there is the greatest admiration for judicial harangues, the nature of which is two-fold, for it consists of accusation and defence.
tgt_text.1388: Of those, though the latter is preferable in point of honour ;
tgt_text.1389: yet the other has often been approved.
tgt_text.1390: I have spoken a little before of Crassus ;
tgt_text.1391: Marcus Antonius when a youth did the same.
tgt_text.1392: An accusation also displayed the eloquence of Publius Sulpicius, when he brought to trial Caius Norba- nus, a seditious and worthless citizen.
tgt_text.1393: But in truth, we ought not to do this frequently nor ever, except for the sake of our country, as in the cases I have mentioned;
tgt_text.1394: or for the purpose of revenge,* as the two Lu- culli did;
tgt_text.1395: or by way of patronage, as I did on behalf of the Sicilians, or as Julius did in the case of Albucius on behalf of the Sardians.
tgt_text.1396: The diligence of Lucius Fufius was dis- played in the impeachment of Manius Aquillius.
tgt_text.1397: For once therefore it may be done;
tgt_text.1398: or at all events not often.
tgt_text.1399: But if a man should be under a necessity of doing it oftener, let him perform it as a duty to his country, for it is by no means blameworthy to carry on repeated prosecutions against her enemies.
tgt_text.1400: But still let moderation be observed.
tgt_text.1401: For it seems to be the part of a cruel man, or rather scar rely of man at all, to endanger the lives of many.
tgt_text.1402: It is both dangerous to your person, and disgraceful to your character, so to act as to get the name of an accuser, as happened in the case of Marcus Brutus, a man sprung from a most noble family, and son to the eminent adept in civil law.
tgt_text.1403: Moreover, this precept of duty also must be carefully ob- served, that you never arraign an innocent man on trial for his life, for this can by no means be done without heinous guilt.
tgt_text.1404: For what can be so unnatural as to prostitute to the persecution and the ruin of the good, that eloquence which nature has given us for the safety and preservation of man- kind.
tgt_text.1405: Although, however, this is to be avoided, yet we are not to consider it a religious duty never to defend a guilty party, so that he be not abominable and impious.
tgt_text.1406: The people desire this, custom tolerates it, and humanity suffers it.
tgt_text.1407: The duty of a judge in all trials is to follow truth;
tgt_text.1408: that of a pleader, sometimes to maintain the plausible though it may not be the truth,* which I should not, especially as I am now treating of philosophy, venture to write, were it not likewise the opinion of a man of the greatest weight among the Stoics.
tgt_text.1410: But it is by defences that glory and favour also are acquired in the greatest degree ;
tgt_text.1411: and so much the greater, if at any time it happens that we come to the help of one who seems to be circumvented and oppressed by the influence of some powerful man, as I myself have done both in other cases frequently, and when a youth in defence of Sextus Roscitis Amerinus, against the influence of Lucius Sylla, then in power, which speech, as you know, is extant.
tgt_text.1413: But having explained the duties of young men, which avail to the attainment of glory, we have next to speak about beneficence and liberality, the nature of which is twofold;
tgt_text.1414: for a kindness is done to those who need it, by giving either our labour or our money.
tgt_text.1415: The latter is easier, especially to a wealthy person ;
tgt_text.1416: but the former is the more noble and splendid, and more worthy of a brave and illus- trious man ;
tgt_text.1417: for although there exists in both a liberal incli- nation to oblige, yet the one is a draft on our purse, the other on our virtue, and bounty which is given out of our income exhausts the very source of the munificence.
tgt_text.1418: Thus benignity is done away by benignity, and the greater the number you have exercised it upon, so much the less able are you to exercise it oil many.
tgt_text.1419: But they who will be beneficent and liberal of their labour, that is, of their virtue and industry, in the first place, will have by how much greater the number of persons they shall have served, so much the more coadjutors in their beneficence.
tgt_text.1420: And in the next place, by the habit of beneficence they will be the better prepared, and, as it were, better exercised to de- serve well of many.
tgt_text.1421: Philip, in a certain letter, admirably reproves his son Alexander, because he sought to gain the goodwill of the Macedonians by largesses—"Pest!" he says, "what consideration led you into the hope that you could imagine that they whom you have corrupted with money would be faithful to you ?
tgt_text.1422: Are you aiming at this, that the Macedonians should expect you will be, not their king, but their agent and purveyor."
tgt_text.1423: He says well, "agent and purveyor," because that is undignified in a king;
tgt_text.1424: and still better, because he designates a largess a corrupt bribe;
tgt_text.1425: for he who receives becomes the worse for it, and more ready always to expect the same.
tgt_text.1426: He enjoined this on his son, but we may consider it a precept for all men.
tgt_text.1427: Wherefore, this indeed is not doubtful, that such beneficence as consists of labour and industry is both the more honourable, and ex- tends more widely, and can serve a greater number.
tgt_text.1428: Some- times, however, we must make presents-nor is this sort of beneficence to be altogether repudiated;
tgt_text.1429: and oftentimes we ought to communicate from our fortune to suitable persons, who are in need, but carefully and moderately.
tgt_text.1430: For many persons have squandered their patrimonies by unadvised ge- nerosity.
tgt_text.1431: Now, what is more absurd than to bring it to pass that you can no longer do that which you would willingly do ?
tgt_text.1433: For when, by giving, they begin to be in want, they are forced to lay their hands upon other men's property.
tgt_text.1434: Thus, when, for the sako of procuring goodwill, they mean to be beneficent, they ac- quire not so much the affection of those to whom they give as the hatred of those from whom they take.
tgt_text.1435: Wherefore, our purse should neither be so closed up that our generosity cannot open it, nor so unfastened that it lies open to all-a bound should be set, and it should bear reference to our means.
tgt_text.1436: We ought altogether to remember that saying which, from being very often used by our countrymen, has come into the usage of a proverb, that bounty has no bottom.
tgt_text.1437: For what bounds can there be, when both they who have been accustomed to receive, and other persons, are desiring the same thing ?XVI.
tgt_text.1438: There are two kinds of men who give largely, of whom one kind are prodigal, the other liberal.
tgt_text.1439: The prodigal are those who with entertainments, and distributions of meat to the populace, and gladiatorial exhibitions, and the appa- ratus of the stage and the chase, lavish their money upon those things of which they will leave behind either a tran- sient memory, or none at all.
tgt_text.1440: But the liberal are they who, with their fortunes, either redeem those captured by robbers, or take up the debts of their friends, or aid in the establish- ing of their daughters, or assist them either in seeking or increasing their fortunes.
tgt_text.1441: Therefore, I am astonished what could come into the mind of Theophrastus, in that book which he wrote about riches, in which he has said many things well, but this most absurdly.
tgt_text.1442: For lie is lavish in praise of magnificence, and of the furnishing of popular exhibitions, and he considers the means of supplying such expenses to be the grand advantage of wealth.
tgt_text.1443: Now, to me that enjoyment of liberality of which I have given a few examples, seems much greater and surer.
tgt_text.1444: With how much more weight and truth does Aristotle censure such of us as feel no astonishment at that profusion of wealth which is wasted in courting the people;
tgt_text.1445: "if," says he, "they who are besieged by an enemy should be compelled to purchase a pint of water at a mina,* this, on first hearing, would seem to us incredible, and all would be astonished, but when we reflect upon it, we excuse it for its necessity;
tgt_text.1446: while in these pieces of immense extravagance and unbounded expense, we do not feel greatly astonished."
tgt_text.1447: And he censures us, especially, "because we are neither relieving necessity, nor is our dignity increased, and the very delight of the multitude is for a brief and little space, and only felt by the most giddy, even in whom, how- ever, at the same time with the satiety, the memory of the pleasure likewise dies."
tgt_text.1448: He sums up well, too, that " these things are agreeable to boys, and silly women, and slaves, and freemen very like slaves;
tgt_text.1449: but that by a man of sense, and one who ponders with sound judgment on such exhibi- tions, they can in no way be approved."
tgt_text.1450: Though I know that in our state it is established by ancient usage, and even now in the good times, that the splendour of ædileships* is expected even from the most excellent men.
tgt_text.1451: Therefore, both Publius Crassus, wealthy as well in name as in fortune, dis- charged the office of ædile with the most magnificent enter- tainment;
tgt_text.1452: and, a little while after, Lucius Crassus, with Quintus Mucius, the most moderate of all men.
tgt_text.1454: and next, Caius Claudius, son of Appius;
tgt_text.1455: many subsequently-the Luculli, Hortensius, Sila- nus;
tgt_text.1456: but Publius Lentulus, in my consulship, surpasssd all his predecessors.
tgt_text.1458: but the shows of my friend Pompey, in his second consulship, were the most magnificent of all-concerning all of whom, you see what is my opinion.
tgt_text.1460: Nevertheless, the suspicion of avarice should be avoided.
tgt_text.1461: The omitting of the ædileship caused the rejection of Mamercus, a very wealthy man, from the consulship.
tgt_text.1462: Wherefore it must be done if it be required by the people, and good men, if not desiring, at least approve it, but in proportion to our means, as I myself did it;
tgt_text.1463: and again, if some object of greater magnitude and utility is acquired by popular largess, as lately the dinners in the streets, under pretext of a vow of a tenth,† brought great honour to Orestes.
tgt_text.1464: Nor was ever any fault found with Marcus Seius, because in the scarcity he gave corn to the people at an as the bushel.
tgt_text.1465: For he delivered himself from a great and in- veterate dislike by an expense neither disgraceful, since he was ædile at the time, nor excessive.
tgt_text.1466: But it lately brought the greatest honour to our friend Milo, that with gladiators, hired for the sake of the republic, which was held together by my safety, he repressed all the attempts and madness of Publius Clodius.
tgt_text.1467: The justification, therefore, of profuse bounty is that it is either necessary or useful.
tgt_text.1468: Moreover, in these very cases the rule of mediocrity is the best.
tgt_text.1469: Lucius Philippus, indeed, the son of Quintus, a man in the highest degree illustrious for his great genius, used to boast that without any expense lie had attained all the highest honours that could be obtained.
tgt_text.1470: Cotta said the same, and Curio.
tgt_text.1471: I myself, too, might in some degree boast on this subject;
tgt_text.1472: for considering the amplitude of the honours which I attained with all the votes in my own* year, too-a thing that happened to none of those whom I have just named-the expense of my ædileship was certainly trifling.
tgt_text.1473: These expenses also are more justifiable on walls, docks, ports, aqueducts, and all things which pertain to the service of the state, though what is given as it were into our hands is more agreeable at present, yet these things are more acceptable to posterity.
tgt_text.1474: Theatres, porticos, new temples, I censure with more reserve for Pompey's sake, but the most learned men disapprove of them, as also this very Panætius, whom in these books I have closely followed, though not translated ;
tgt_text.1475: and Demetrius Phalereus, who censures Pericles, the greatest man of Greece, because he lavished so much money on that glorious vestibule ;
tgt_text.1476: † but all this subject I have carefully discussed in those books which I have written upon Government.
tgt_text.1477: The whole plan, then, of such largesses is vicious in its nature, but necessitated by particular occa- sions, and even then ought to be accommodated to our means, and regulated by moderation.
tgt_text.1479: But in that second kind of munificence which proceeds from liberality, we ought in different cases to be affected in different manners.
tgt_text.1480: The case is different of him who is oppressed with misfortune, and of him who seeks to better his fortune without being in any adversity.
tgt_text.1481: Our benignity will require to be more prompt toward the dis- tressed, unless perhaps they merit their distress ;
tgt_text.1482: yet from those who desire to be assisted, not that they may be relieved from affliction, but that they may ascend to a higher degree, we ought by no means to be altogether restricted, but to apply judgment and discretion in selecting proper persons.
tgt_text.1483: For Ennius observes well-" Benefactions ill bestowed, I deem malefactions.
tgt_text.1484: "But in that which is bestowed upon a worthy and grateful man there is profit, as well from himself as also from others ;
tgt_text.1485: for liberality, when free from rashness, is most agreeable, and many applaud it the more earnestly on this account, because the bounty of every very exalted man is the common refuge of all.
tgt_text.1486: We should do our endeavour, then, that we may serve as many as possible with those benefits, the recol- lection of which may be handed down to their children and posterity, that it may not be in their power to be ungrateful;

tgt_text.2623: Wherefore, to be afflicted at this his departure, I fear, would be the part rather of an envious person than of a friend.
tgt_text.2624: But if, on the other hand, this be rather the truth, that the death of the soul and of the body is one and the same, and that no consciousness remains;
tgt_text.2625: as there is no advantage in death, so certainly there is no evil.
tgt_text.2626: For when consciousness is lost, it becomes the same as if he had never been born at all;
tgt_text.2627: yet, both we ourselves are glad, and this state, as long as it shall exist, will rejoice that he was born.
tgt_text.2628: Wherefore (as I said above) with him indeed all ended well:
tgt_text.2630: for it had been more equitable that, as I entered upon life first, I should likewise first depart from it.
tgt_text.2631: But yet I so enjoy the recollection of our friendship, that I seem to have lived happily because I lived with Scipio:
tgt_text.2632: with whom I had a common anxiety on pub- lie and private affairs, and with whom my life both at home and abroad was associated, and there existed that, wherein con- sists the entire strength of friendship, an entire agreement of inclinations, pursuits, and sentiments.*
tgt_text.2633: That character for wis- dom, therefore, which Fannius a little while ago mentioned, does not so delight me, especially since it is undeserved, as the hope that the recollection of our friendship will last for ever.
tgt_text.2634: And it is the more gratifying to me, because scarcely in the history of the world are three or four pairs of friends mentioned by name;
tgt_text.2635: † and I indulge in the hope that the friendship of Scipio and Lælius will be known to posterity in this class.- FANNIUS.
tgt_text.2636: Indeed, Lælius, that must be so.
tgt_text.2637: But since you have made mention of friendship, and as we have leisure, you will do what is very agreeable to me (I hope also to Scævola), if, as your custom is concerning other matters when your opinion of them is asked, so you would descant on friendship, [telling us] what is your opinion, of what nature you con- sider it to be, and what directions you would lay down.- SCÆVOLA.
tgt_text.2638: To me it will be exceedingly agreeable;
tgt_text.2639: and in fact, when I was endeavouring to prevail with you, Fannius anticipated me :

tgt_text.2641: I indeed should not object, if I could feel confidence in myself ;
tgt_text.2642: for not only is the subject a splendid one, but we, as Fannius said, have nothing to do.

tgt_text.2645: This is the practice of scholars, and of Grecian scholars, that a subject be given them on which they are to dispute, however suddenly.
