tgt_text.2647: Wherefore, as to what may be said on the subject of friendship, I recommend you to seek it from those who pro- fess such things.*
tgt_text.2648: I can only urge you to prefer friendship to all human possessions ;
tgt_text.2649: for there is nothing so suited to our nature, so well adapted to prosperity or adversity.
tgt_text.2650: But first of all, I am of opinion, that except amongst the virtuous, friendship cannot exist:
tgt_text.2651: I do not analyse this principle too closely, as they do who inquire with too great nicety into those things, perhaps with truth on their side, but with little ge- neral advantage ;
tgt_text.2652: for they maintain that there is no good man but the wise man.
tgt_text.2654: yet they define wisdom to be such as no mortal has ever attained to:
tgt_text.2655: whereas we ought to contemplate these things which exist in practice and in common life, and not the subjects of fictions or of our own wishes.
tgt_text.2656: I would never pretend to say that Caius Fabricius, :
tgt_text.2657: larius Curius, and Titus Coruncanius, whom our ancestors esteemed wise, were wise according to the standard of these moralists.
tgt_text.2658: Wherefore let them keep to themselves the name of wisdom, both invidious and unintelligible ;
tgt_text.2659: and let them allow that these were, good men—nay, they will not even do that;
tgt_text.2660: they will declare that this cannot be granted except to a wise man.
tgt_text.2661: Let us therefore proceed with our dull genius, as they say.
tgt_text.2662: Those who so conduct themselves, and so live that their honour, their integrity, their justice, and liberality are approved;
tgt_text.2663: so that there is not in them any covetousness, or licentiousness, or boldness;
tgt_text.2664: and that they are of great consistency, as those men whom I have mentioned above ;
tgt_text.2665: - let us consider these worthy of the appellation of good men, as they have been accounted such, because they follow (as far as men are able) nature, which is the best guide of a good life.*
tgt_text.2666: For I seem to myself to have this view, that we are so formed by nature, that there should be a certain social tie among all ;
tgt_text.2667: stronger, however, as each approaches nearer to us.
tgt_text.2668: Accordingly, citizens are preferable to foreigners, and relations to strangers ;
tgt_text.2669: for with the latter, nature herself has created a friendly feeling, though this has not sufficient strength.
tgt_text.2670: For in this respect friendship is superior to relationship, because from relationship benevo- lence can be withdrawn, and from friendship it cannot:
tgt_text.2671: for with the withdrawal of benevolence the very name of friend- ship is done away, while that of relationship remains.
tgt_text.2672: Now how great the power of friendship is, may be best gathered from this consideration, that out of the boundless society of the human race, which nature herself has joined together, friendship is a matter so contracted, and brought into so narrow a compass, that the whole of affection is confined to two, or at any rate to very few.
tgt_text.2674: Now friendship is nothing else than a complete union of feeling on all subjects, divine and human, accompanied by kindly feeling and attachment ;
tgt_text.2675: than which, indeed, I am not aware whether, with the exception of wisdom, anything better has been bestowed on man by the immortal gods.
tgt_text.2676: Some men prefer riches, others good health, others influence, others again honours, many prefer even pleasures :
tgt_text.2677: the last, indeed, is the characteristic of beasts ;
tgt_text.2678: while the former are fleeting and uncertain, depending not so much on our own purpose, as on the fickleness of fortune.
tgt_text.2679: Whereas those who place the supreme good in virtue, therein do admirably :
tgt_text.2680: but this very virtue itself both begets and constitutes friendship;
tgt_text.2681: nor without this virtue can friendship exist at all.
tgt_text.2682: Now let us define this virtue according to the usage of life, and of our common language ;
tgt_text.2683: and let us not measure it, as certain learned persons do, by pomp of language ;
tgt_text.2684: and let us include among the good those who are so accounted-the Paulli, the Gates, the Galli, the Scipios, and the Phili ;
tgt_text.2685: with these men ordinary life is content:
tgt_text.2686: and let us pass over those who are nowhere found to exist.
tgt_text.2687: Amongst men of this kind, therefore, friendship finds facilities so great that I can scarcely describe them.
tgt_text.2688: In the first place-to whom can life be “ worth living," as Ennius says, who does not repose ton the mutual kind feeling of some friend ?
tgt_text.2689: What can be more delightful than to have one to whom you can speak on .
tgt_text.2690: all subjects just as to yourself?
tgt_text.2691: Where would be the great enjoyment in prosperity, if you had not one to rejoice in it equally with yourself?
tgt_text.2692: And adversity would indeed be difficult to endure, without some one who would bear it even with greater regret than yourself.
tgt_text.2693: In short, all other objects that are sought after, are severally suited to some one single purpose :
tgt_text.2694: riches, that you may spend them ;
tgt_text.2695: power, that you may be courted;
tgt_text.2696: honours, that you may be extolled;
tgt_text.2697: pleasures, that you may enjoy them ;
tgt_text.2698: good health, that you may be exempt from harm, and perform the functions of the body.
tgt_text.2699: Whereas friendship comprises the greatest number of objects possible :
tgt_text.2700: wherever you turn yourself, it is at hand ;
tgt_text.2701: shut out of no place, never out of season, never irksome ;
tgt_text.2702: and therefore we do not use fire and water, as they say, on more occasions than we do friendship.
tgt_text.2703: And I am not now speaking of common-place cr ordinary friendship (though even that brings delight and benefit), but of real and true friendship, such as belonged to those of whom very few are recorded :
tgt_text.2704: for prosperity, friendship renders more brilliant;
tgt_text.2705: and adversity more supportable, by dividing and communi- cating it.*VII.
tgt_text.2706: And while friendship embraces very many and great advantages, she undoubtedly surpasses all in this, that she shines with a brilliant hope over the future, and never suffers the spirit to be weakened or to sink.
tgt_text.2707: Besides, he who looks on a true friend, looks as it were upon a kind of image of himself:
tgt_text.2708: wherefore friends, though absent, are still present;
tgt_text.2709: though in poverty, they are rich ;
tgt_text.2710: though weak, yet in the enjoyment of health ;
tgt_text.2711: and, what is still more difficult to assert, though dead they are alive ;
tgt_text.2712: so entirely does the honour, the memory, the regret of friends attend them ;
tgt_text.2713: from which circumstance, the death of the one seems to be happy, and the life of the other praiseworthy :
tgt_text.2714: nay, should you remove from nature the cement of kind feelings, neither a house nor a city will be able to stand ;
tgt_text.2715: even the cultivation of the land will not continue.
tgt_text.2716: If it be not clearly perceived how great is the power of friendship and concord, it can be dis- tinctly inferred from quarrels and dissensions;
tgt_text.2717: for what house is there so established, or what state so firmly settled, that may not utterly be overthrown by hatred and dissension ?
tgt_text.2718: from which it may be determined how much advantage there is in friendship.
tgt_text.2719: They relate, indeed, that a certain learned man of Agrigentum* promulgated in Greek verses the doctrine, that all things which cohere throughout the whole world, and all things that are the subjects of motion, are brought together by friendship, and are dispelled by discord ;
tgt_text.2720: and this principle all men understand, and illustrate by their conduct.
tgt_text.2721: Therefore, if at any time any act of a friend has been exhibited, either in undergoing or in sharing dangers, who is there that does not extol such an act with the highest praise ?
tgt_text.2722: What shouts of applause were lately heard through the whole theatre, on the occasion of a new play by my guest and friend, Marcus Pacuvius, when the king, being ignorant which of them was Orestes, Pylades said he was Orestes, that he might be put to death instead of him ;
tgt_text.2723: but Orestes, as was the fact, solemnly maintained that he was the man ?
tgt_text.2724: They stood up and applauded in an imaginary case :
tgt_text.2725: what must we suppose they would have done in a real one Nature herself excellently asserted her rightful power, when tnen pronounced that to be rightly done in another, which they could not do themselves.
tgt_text.2726: Thus far I seem to have been able to lay down what are my sentiments concerning friend- ship.

tgt_text.2729: But we would rather hear it from you ;
tgt_text.2730: although 1 have often asked such questions, and heard their opinions, and that not without satisfaction, yet what we desire is the somewhat different thread of your discourse.

tgt_text.2736: What shall we say then of friendship ?

tgt_text.2740: Why, this is using force against one :
tgt_text.2741: for what matters it by what kind of request you compel me ?
tgt_text.2743: For to oppose the wishes of one's sons-in-law, especially in a good matter, is not only hard, but it is not even just.
tgt_text.2744: After very often, then, reflect- ing on the subject of friendship, this question seems to me especially worthy of consideration, whether friendship has become an object of desire, on account of weakness or want, so that by giving and receiving favours, each may receive from another, and mutually repay, what he is himself in- capable of acquiring.
tgt_text.2745: Or whether this is only a property of friendship ;
tgt_text.2746: whilst there is another cause, higher and nobler, and more directly derived from nature herself ?
tgt_text.2747: For love (from which friendship takes its name) is the main motive for the union of kind feelings:
tgt_text.2748: for advantages truly are often derived from those who are courted under a pretence of friendship, and have attention paid them for a temporary purpose.
tgt_text.2749: In friendship there is nothing false, and nothing pretended ;
tgt_text.2750: and whatever belongs to it is sincere and spon- taneous.
tgt_text.2751: Wherefore friendship seems to me to have sprung rather from nature than from a sense of want, and more from an attachment of the mind with a certain feeling of affection, than from a calculation how much advantage it would afford.
tgt_text.2752: And of what nature indeed it is, may be observed in the case of certain beasts ;
tgt_text.2753: for they love their offspring up to a certain time, and are loved by them in such a way that their emotions are easily discovered.
tgt_text.2754: And this is much more evi- dent in man.
tgt_text.2755: In the first place, from that affection which subsists between children and parents, which cannot be de- stroyed without detestable wickedness :
tgt_text.2756: next, where a similar feeling of love has existed, if we have met with any one with whose character and disposition we sympathize, because we appear to discover in him a certain effulgence as it were of integrity and virtue.
tgt_text.2757: For nothing is more amiable than virtue, nothing which more strongly allures us to love it, seeing that because of their virtue and integrity we can in a certain degree love those whom we have never seen.
tgt_text.2758: Who can mention the name of Caius Fabricius, and Marius Curius, otherwise than with love and affection, though he never saw them ?
tgt_text.2759: Who can forbear hating Tarquinius Superbus, Spurius Cassius, and Spurius Mælius ?
tgt_text.2760: Against two generals we had a struggle for empire in Italy, I mean Pyrrhus and Hannibal ;
tgt_text.2761: towards the former, on account of his honourable conduct, we bear not a very hostile disposition;
tgt_text.2762: while this state will always detest the latter for his cruelty.
tgt_text.2764: Now if such be the influence of integrity, that we love it even in those whom we have never seen, and, what is much more, even in an enemy, what wonder if men's feelings are affected when they seem to discover the goodness and virtue of those with whom they may become connected by Intercourse ?
tgt_text.2765: although love is confirmed by the reception of kindness, and by the discovery of an earnest sympathy, and by close familiarity ;
tgt_text.2766: which things being added to the first emotion of the mind and the affections, there is kindled a large amount of kindly feeling.
tgt_text.2767: And if any imagine that this proceeds from a sense of weakness, so that there shall bd secured a friend, by whom a man may obtain that which he wants, they leave to friendship a mean indeed, and, if I may so speak, anything but respectable origin, when they make her to be born of indigence and want:
tgt_text.2768: were this the case, then in proportion as a man judged that there were the least resources in himself, precisely in that degree would he be best qualified for friendship:
tgt_text.2769: whereas the fact is far otherwise.
tgt_text.2770: For just as a man has most confidence in himself, and as he is most completely fortified by worth and wisdom, so that he needs no one's assistance, and feels that all his resources reside in himself;
tgt_text.2771: in the same proportion he is most highly distinguished for seeking out and forming friendships.
tgt_text.2772: For what did Africanus want of me ?
tgt_text.2774: nor indeed did I need aught from him :
tgt_text.2775: but I loved him from admiration of his excellence;
tgt_text.2776: lie in turn perhaps was at- tached to me from some high opinion which he entertained of my character, and association fostered our affection.
tgt_text.2777: But although many and great advantages ensued, yet it was not from any hope of these that the causes of our attachment sprang:
tgt_text.2778: for as we are beneficent and liberal, not to exact favour in return (for we are not usurers in kind actions), but by nature are inclined to liberality, thus I think that friend- ship is to be desired, not attracted by the hope of reward, but because the whole of its profit consists in love only.
tgt_text.2779: From such opinions, they who, after the fashion of beasts, refer everything to pleasure, widely differ:
tgt_text.2780: and no great wonder, since they cannot look up to anything lofty, magnificent, or divine, who cast all their thoughts on an object so mean and contemptible.
tgt_text.2781: Therefore let us exclude such persons altogether from our discourse;
tgt_text.2782: and let us ourselves hold this opinion, that the sentiment of loving, and the attachment of kind feelings, are produced by nature, when the evidence of virtue has been established;
tgt_text.2783: and they who have eagerly sought the latter, draw nigh and attach themselves to it, that they may enjoy the friendship and character of the individual they have begun to love, and that they may be commensurate and equal in affection, and more inclined to confer a favour than to claim any return.
tgt_text.2784: And let this honourable struggle be maintained between them ;
tgt_text.2785: so not only will the greatest advantages be derived from friendship, but its origin from nature rather than from a sense of weakness, will be at once more impressive and more true.
tgt_text.2786: For if it were expediency that cemented friendships, the same when changed would dissolve them;
tgt_text.2787: but because nature can never change, there- fore true friendships are eternal.
tgt_text.2788: Thus you see the origin of friendship, unless you wish to make some reply to these views.
tgt_text.2790: Xay, go on, Lælius, for I answer for Scæola here (who is my junior) on my own authority.-
tgt_text.2795: Listen, then, my excellent friends, to the discussion which was very frequently held by me and Scipio on the subject of friendship;
tgt_text.2796: although he indeed used to say that nothing was more difficult than that friendship should continue to the end of life;
tgt_text.2797: for it often happened, either that the same course was not expedient to both parties, or that they held different views of politics :
tgt_text.2798: he also remarked that the characters of men often changed;
tgt_text.2799: in some cases by adversity, in others by old age becoming oppressive;
tgt_text.2800: and he derived an authority for such notions from a comparison with early life, because the strongest attachment of boys are con- stantly laid aside with the prætexta;
tgt_text.2801: even if they should main- tain it to manhood, yet sometimes it is broken off by rivalry, for a dowried wife, or some other advantage, which they cannot both attain.
tgt_text.2802: And even if men should be carried on still further in their friendship, yet that feeling is often undermined, should they fall into rivalry for preferments ;
tgt_text.2803: for there is no greater enemy to friendship than covet- ousness of money, in most men, and even in the best, an emulous desire of high offices and glory;
tgt_text.2804: in consequence of which the most bitter enmities have often arisen between the dearest friends.
tgt_text.2805: For great dissensions, and those in most instances justifiable, arise, when some request is made of friends which is improper ;
tgt_text.2806: as, for instance, that they should become either the ministers of their lust or their supporters in the perpetration of wrong ;
tgt_text.2807: and they who refuse to do so, it matters not however virtuously, yet are accused of dis- carding the claims of friendship by those persons whom they are unwilling to oblige;
tgt_text.2808: but they who dare to ask anything of a friend, by their very request seem to imply that they would do anything for the sake of that friend:
tgt_text.2809: by the coin- plaining of such persons, not only are long-established intimacies put an end to, but endless animosities are engen- dered.
tgt_text.2810: All these many causes, like so many fatalities, are ever threatening friendship, so that, he said, to escape them all, seemed to him a proof not merely of wisdom, but even of good fortune.
tgt_text.2812: Wherefore let us first consider, if you please, how far love ought to proceed in friendship.
tgt_text.2813: If Coriolanus had friends, were they bound to carry arms against their country with Coriolanus?
tgt_text.2814: Were their friends bound to support Viscellinus or Spurius Mælius when they aimed at the sovereignty?
tgt_text.2815: Nay, in the case of Tiberius Gracchus, when disturbing the commonwealth, we saw him totally abandoned by Quintus Tubero, and other friends of his own standing.
tgt_text.2816: But in the case of Caius Blossius, of Cumæ, the friend of cur family, Scævola, when he had come to me (then attend- ing upon the consuls Lænas and Rupilius in their council) to sue for pardon, he brought forward his plea, that he es- teemed Tiberius Gracchus so highly, that he thought it his duty to do whatever he wished.
tgt_text.2817: So I said, "What, even if he wished you to set fire to the capitol?" "
tgt_text.2818: He never would have thought of that," he replied. "
tgt_text.2821: You see what an abominable speech:
tgt_text.2822: and, by Hercules, he did so, and even worse than he said;
tgt_text.2823: for he did not follow the mad schemes of Tiberius Gracchus, but in fact headed them, and did not act as the accomplice of his violence, but even as the captain.
tgt_text.2824: There- fore in consequence of such rashness, being terrified by a new prosecution, he fled precipitately into Asia, joined the enemy, and atoned to the commonwealth by a punishment just and severe.
tgt_text.2825: It is no excuse therefore for a fault;
tgt_text.2826: that you committed it for a friend's sake;
tgt_text.2827: for since the belief in another's excellence was that which conciliated friendship, it is hard for friendship to continue when you have apostatized from virtue.
tgt_text.2828: Now if we shall lay it down as right, either to concede to friends whatever they wish, or to obtain from them whatever we wish, we must have indeed consummate wisdom, if such a course leads to no vice.
tgt_text.2829: But we are speak- ing of those friends who are before our eyes, whom we see around us, or else whom we know by report, and with whom every-day life is familiar:
tgt_text.2830: from that class we must take our instances, and, above all, from those who make the nearest approaches to wisdom.
tgt_text.2831: We see that Papus Æmilius was the intimate friend of Caius Luscinus (so we have learned from our fathers) ;
tgt_text.2832: that they were twice consuls together, and col- leagues in the censorship ;
tgt_text.2833: and that at the same time Marcus Curius and Titus Coruncanius were most intimate with them and with each other, is a matter of history, and there- fore we cannot even suspect that any one of these ever asked his friend anything that was contrary to their honour, their oath, and the interest of the state:
tgt_text.2834: for what reason is there for making such a remark about men like them ?
tgt_text.2835: I am convinced, had any of them made the request, lie would not have obtained it, for they were men of the purest prin- ciple ;
tgt_text.2836: besides, it would be equally as wrong to agree to any such request when made, as to make it.
tgt_text.2837: And yet Caius Caibo and Caius Cato both took the part of Tiberius Grac- chus, as did his brother Cains, at that time by no means an agitator, but now one of the most violentXII.
tgt_text.2838: Let this law therefore be established in friendship, viz., that we should neither ask things that are improper, nor grant them when asked;
tgt_text.2839: for it is a disgraceful apology, and by no means to be admitted, as well in the case of other offences, as when any one avows he has acted against the state for the sake of a friend.*

tgt_text.2841: for the practice of our ancestors has already in some respect swerved from its career and course.

tgt_text.2868: Let this, therefore, be established as a primary law concerning friendship, that we expect from our friends only what is honourable, and for our friends' sake do what is honourable;
tgt_text.2869: that we should not wait till we are asked;
tgt_text.2870: that zeal be ever ready, and reluctance far from us;
tgt_text.2871: but that we take pleasure in freely giving our advice;
tgt_text.2872: that in our friendship, the influence of our friends, when they give good advice, should have great weight;
tgt_text.2873: and that this be em- ployed to admonish not only candidly, but even severely, if the case shall require, and that we give heed to it when so employed;

tgt_text.2945: But it is required to lay down what limits there are in friendship, and, as it were, what bounds of loving, con- cerning which I see three opinions held, of none of which I approve :

tgt_text.4408: one of which (which is the outermost) is heaven, and compre- hends all the rest, (inhabited by) that all-powerful God, who bounds and controls the others ;
tgt_text.4409: and in this sphere reside the original principles of those endless revolutions which the planets perform.
tgt_text.4410: Within this are contained seven other spheres, that turn round backwards, that is, in a con- trary direction to that of the heaven.
tgt_text.4411: Of these, that planet which on earth you call Saturn, occupies one sphere.
tgt_text.4412: That shining body which you see next is called Jupiter, and is friendly and salutary to mankind.
tgt_text.4413: Next the lucid one, ter- rible to the earth, which you call Mars.

tgt_text.4507: Now as it has so happened that neither the prætors by their interest, nor I by my zeal, were able to effect any thing, it is certainly difficult not to feel mortification at it, but yet we ought never to suffer our minds which are employed in managing and supporting the arduous affairs of government to be crushed or dejected by misfortune.
tgt_text.4508: And because men ought to be most annoyed by those ills which are incurred by their own faults, there is in this transaction somewhat more afflicting to me than ought to be to you, for it happened by my misconduct contrary to your understanding with me when parting, and subsequently by letters, that your successor was not named last year.
tgt_text.4509: This I did unwisely, with a view of consulting the welfare of our allies, of crushing the presumptuousness of certain traders,t and with the desire of increasing my own glory through your merits ;

tgt_text.4511: Having thus frankly acknowledged that it was my fault, it is the part of your wisdom and kindness to take care and manage that this which has been unwisely schemed by me may be corrected by your diligence ;
tgt_text.4512: and surely, if you exert yourself in all the duties of government so as to seem to vie not only with others but with yourself, if you call in use all your faculties, all your attention, all your thought, to that love of glory, which is so powerfully prevalent in all trans- actions, believe me, that one year added to your toil will bring many years of pleasure to us, and even glory to our posterity.
tgt_text.4513: Wherefore, I in the first place beg of you, that you will not suffer your spirit to be damped or diminished, nor yourself to be overwhelmed, as with a flood, by the multitude of business;
tgt_text.4514: but that, on the contrary, you will arouse yourself, and make a firm stand, even if you spon- taneously incur it;
tgt_text.4515: for you do not bear a part in such a government as is governed by fortune, but one in which discretion and diligence has the greatest influence.
tgt_text.4516: Had I seen your command prolonged at a time when you were involved in the management of some great and dangerous war, then I should have been disquieted in my mind, because I should have been sensible that the power of fortune over us was prolonged at the same time.
tgt_text.4517: But since that depart- ment of the state has been committed to you in which fortune has very little or no part, it seems to me to depend entirely on your own virtue and wisdom.
tgt_text.4518: We apprehend, I think, no treachery of enemies ;

tgt_text.4539: Again, what can be a more distinguished, a more desirable circum- stance, than that this virtue, this moderation, this purity of mind, should not be buried or concealed in darkness, but dis- played in the sight of Asia, to the eyes of the noblest of our provinces, and to the ears of all people and nations.

tgt_text.4547: It is necessary that lie should both be moderate by his own inclination, and conform himself to your arrangements and directions.
tgt_text.4548: Should any of your officers appear of a more selfish dis- position, you should bear with him, so long as he only neglects the laws by which he is bound in his own person, but not if he should prostitute for interest that power which you have annexed to his office.
tgt_text.4549: It does not however seem desirable to me, especially as our manners have lately leaned so much to laxity and ambition, that you should scrutinize and dissect out every instance of corruption ;
tgt_text.4550: * but to pro- portion the trust you repose in every one, according to the degree of honesty he possesses.
tgt_text.4551: In like manner you should be answerable for those whom our government has given you as assessors and assistants, only under the restrictions which I have already laid down.
tgt_text.4552: As to those whom you have chosen to belong to your domestic establishment, or to be with you as your necessary retinue, and who are accustomed to be designated as of the prætor's cohort, you are answerable, not only for all their actions, but for all their sayings.
tgt_text.4553: But you have about your person those whom you may easily love while they act rightly ;
tgt_text.4554: and such as but slightly consult your reputation you can most easily coerce.
tgt_text.4555: Meanwhile it is natural to suppose, that, while you were inexperienced, your generosity might have been imposed upon ;
tgt_text.4556: for the more virtuous any man is in himself, the less easily does he suspect others to be vicious.
tgt_text.4557: fBut now let this third year be distinguished by the same purity which marked the two former, and even by more caution and diligence.
tgt_text.4558: Let your ears be such as are supposed to hear what they listen to, but not into which things may be falsely and dishonestly whispered for the sake of gain, without being the receptacles of false and malicious whispers, insinuations, and complaints.
tgt_text.4559: Suffer not your seal to be a common chattel, but as your very self;
tgt_text.4560: let it not be the tool of another's pleasure, but the evidence of your own.
tgt_text.4561: Let your pursuivant keep the rank which our ancestors assigned to him, who did not rashly entrust that office to any but freed men, over whom they exercised pretty much the same command, as they did over their slaves, and that not as a post of advantage but of labour and service.
tgt_text.4562: Let the lictor be the agent of your lenity rather than of his own, and let i his axe and his rods be stronger evidences of his post than of his power.
tgt_text.4563: In short, let all the province be sensible how dearly you prize the welfare, the children, the fame, and the fortunes of all who are under your command.
tgt_text.4564: Let it be notorious that you will be equally the enemy of the man who gives, as of him who receives a present, if you shall know it;
tgt_text.4565: for no one will give them, when it shall be clearly perceived that those who pretend to have the greatest interest with you are ac- customed to obtain nothing from you.
tgt_text.4566: Yet this address of mine to you is not because I would have you treat your dependants in a too severe or suspicious manner.
tgt_text.4567: For if any of them for two years have never fallen under suspicion of avarice, as I hear Cæsius, Chærippus, and Labeo, have done, and I believe it because I know them well;
tgt_text.4568: there is nothing which I should not think may be most properly committed to them and to men of their character.
tgt_text.4569: But if there is a man, from whom you have already received offence, or of whom you have known any- thing ill, never entrust anything to him, nor commit to him any portion of your reputation.
tgt_text.4570: But if within your province you have got any person who has been thoroughly admitted to your intimacy, and who is unknown to me, consider how far you ought to trust him.
tgt_text.4571: Not but that there may be many worthy men amongst the provincials ;
tgt_text.4572: but this it is lawful to hope, but dangerous to determine.
tgt_text.4573: For every man's nature is concealed with many folds of disguise, and covered as it were with various veils.
tgt_text.4574: His nature, his brows, his eyes, and very often his countenance are deceitful, and -his speech is most commonly a lie.
tgt_text.4575: Wherefore, out of that class of men who, being devoted to the love of money, are destitute of all those qualities from which we cannot be separated, where can you find one who will sincerely love you, a mere stranger to them.
tgt_text.4576: and not pretend to do so for the sake of advantage ?
tgt_text.4577: It would seem to me very extraordinary, especially as those very men pay seldom any regard to any private man, while they are all invariably attached themselves to the prætors.
tgt_text.4578: However, if amongst such kind of men you should find one (for the thing is not impossible), who loves you more than he does his own interest, eagerly enrol such a man in the number of your friends ;
tgt_text.4579: but if you do not perceive this, there will be no class in your acquaintance more to be avoided :
tgt_text.4580: because they know all the arts of getting money, they Jo nothing but for money, and they are indifferent about the opinion of any man with whom they are not to continue to live.
tgt_text.4581: Certain connections too with the Greeks themselves are to be most carefully guarded against, except with a very few men, who, if any, are worthy of ancient Greece.
tgt_text.4582: For truly, in general they are deceitful and treacherous, and trained up by perpetual subjection, in the art of sycophancy.*
tgt_text.4583: All of these I would say should be liberally treated, and the best of them received into hospitality and friendship ;
tgt_text.4584: but too close intimacies with them are not very safe, for though they dare not oppose our wishes, yet they are jealous not only of our countrymen but even of their own.
tgt_text.4585: Though they dare not fly in the face of a Roman magistrate, yet at the bottom they hate not only us but their own countrymen.
tgt_text.4586: Now, as in matters of this kind, as I wish to be cautious and diligent (though I fear I may seem too rigid), what do you think is my feeling with respect to slaves, whom we ought to keep under the strictest commmand in all places, but especially in the provinces ?
tgt_text.4587: Concerning this class many directions might be given ;
tgt_text.4588: but the shortest and plainest method I can recommend is, that in all your Asiatic journeys, they should behave as if you were travelling over the Appian way, and that they think there is not the least difference whether they were entering Tralles † or Formiæ.‡
tgt_text.4589: But if any of your slaves should distinguish himself by his fidelity, let him be employed in your domestic and private affairs, but not let him have the smallest thing to do with any public concern, or anything relating to the business of your government.
tgt_text.4590: For though many things may properly be entrusted to our faithful slaves, yet for the sake of avoid- ing observation and animadversion, they ought not to be committed to them.
tgt_text.4591: But I know not how my discourse has deviated into a style of dictation, though that was not my intention at the com- mencement.
tgt_text.4592: For why should I dictate to a man not inferior to me in knowledge, especially in all matters of this kind, and even superior in experience ?
tgt_text.4593: but I thought it would be very agreeable, if my sanction were added to what you are doing.
tgt_text.4594: Wherefore let these be the foundations of your dignity.
tgt_text.4595: In the first place, your own integrity and modera- tion ;
tgt_text.4596: in the next place, the modest behaviour of all who are about you, joined to a very cautious and circumspect choice of your acquaintance, whether they be provincials or Greeks;
tgt_text.4597: and the orderly and consistent regulation of your household.
tgt_text.4598: All which particulars are commendable in our private and daily concerns, but they must appear divine amidst such great power, such depraved manners, and so corrupting a province.
tgt_text.4599: Such a plan, and such regulations, will be sufficient to support that severity in all your resolutions, and all your decrees, which you exercised in those matters, and by which, to my great pleasure, we have incurred some enmities, unless, indeed, you imagine that I was influenced by the complaints of an individual—I know not whom-of the name of Paconius, who is not even a Greek, but is some Mysian, or rather Phrygian;
tgt_text.4600: or that I was moved by the vociferations of Tuscenius, that frantic, mean-spirited wretch, from whose polluted maw you, with the utmost equity, rescued a dis- honest prey.
tgt_text.4601: Wherefore we could not easily maintain those and the other instances of severity which you have practised in that province, without the most perfect integrity.
tgt_text.4602: There should therefore be the utmost rigour in your ad- ministration of justice, so that it should not be affected by favour, but maintained without variation.*
tgt_text.4603: It is, however, of no great consequence that justice should be impartially and diligently administered by yourself, unless the same is done 'by those to whom you have delegated some part of your functions.
tgt_text.4604: Now it appears to me that in the government of Asia there is no great variety of business, but that it is chiefly employed in judicial administration, the method of which especially in provinces is simple.
tgt_text.4605: Constancy and gravity must indeed be exercised, which may be not only above partiality, but even above the suspicion of it.
tgt_text.4606: To this must be added affability in hearing, calmness in determining, and carefulness in discussing the case and making restitu- tion.
tgt_text.4607: By reason of these qualities, Octavius* lately became most popular, before whom, for the first time, the lictor had nothing to do, and the crier had nothing to say;
tgt_text.4608: for every one spoke when he pleased and as long as he pleased.
tgt_text.4609: In this matter he might, perhaps, seem too compliant, were it not that this gentleness was the warrant of his inflexibility.
tgt_text.4610: The men of Sylla's party were compelled to restore what they had seized by force and terror.
tgt_text.4611: Such of the magistrates as had made unjust decisions were obliged themselves to submit, as private men, to similar inflictions.
tgt_text.4612: Now this severity on his part would have seemed cruel, had it not been tempered with many ingredients of humanity.
tgt_text.4613: If this gentleness is agreeable at Rome, where there is so much arrogance, such unbounded liberty, such unrestrained licentiousness, where there are such numerous magistracies, so many auxiliaries, so great force, and so much authority in the senate, how agreeable must the affability of a prætor be in Asia, where so great a number of our countrymen and allies, where so many cities and so many states, are observant ofone man's nod ?
tgt_text.4614: where they have no resource, no tribunal, no senate, and no assembly of the people ?
tgt_text.4615: It belongs there- fore to the character of a great man, and of a man as well humane by nature, as improved by learning and the study of the noblest arts, so to conduct himself in the use of such great power as that no other authority should be desired by those over whom he rules.
tgt_text.4616: The great Cyrus is represented by Xenophon (not accord- ing to the truth of history, but as the ideal model of right government*), whose extreme gravity is combined by that philosopher with singular sweetness of manners;
tgt_text.4617: which books our countryman, Scipio Africanus, was accustomed, and not without reason, always to have in his hands, for in them no duty of active, well-tempered government has been passed over;
tgt_text.4618: and if Cyrus, who could never be reduced to a private station, so diligently cultivated those duties, what ought they to be held by those to whom power has been given on con- dition of their surrendering it, and given by those laws to which they must be amenable ?
tgt_text.4619: Now it seems to me that all the considerations of those who rule over others should be referred to this object, that those who are under their government should be as happy as possible;
tgt_text.4620: and by constant report, and the acknowledgment of all, it has become no honour that this both is, and ever has been your most settled principle ever since you first landed in Asia;
tgt_text.4621: nay, that it is the duty, not only of those who govern the allies and the subjects of Rome, but of those who have the care of slaves and dumb cattle, to con- tribute to the interests and welfare of all committed to their charge.
tgt_text.4622: In this respect I perceive it is universally allowed that the utmost diligence has been used by you;
tgt_text.4623: that no new debts have been contracted by the states;
tgt_text.4624: that you have dis- charged many old ones with which many of the cities were burdened and oppressed;
tgt_text.4625: that you have repaired many ruin- ous and almost abandoned towns;
tgt_text.4626: amongst others Samus the capital of Ionia, and Halicarnassus the capital of Caria;
tgt_text.4627: that there are no seditions, no discords in your towns;
tgt_text.4628: that it has been seen to by you that the states are governed by the counsels of the best men;
tgt_text.4629: that you have suppressed rapine in Mysia, and bloodshed in many places;
tgt_text.4630: that peace has been established all over your province;
tgt_text.4631: that you have chased thieves and robbers, not only from the highways and country places, but from towns and temples, where they were more numerous and more dangerous;
tgt_text.4632: that calumny, that most cruel minister to the avarice of prætors, has been removed from the reputation, the fortunes, and the retire- ment of the rich;
tgt_text.4633: that the funds and taxes of the states are equally borne by all who inhabit the borders of those states;
tgt_text.4634: that access to you is most easy;
tgt_text.4635: that your ears are open to the complaints of all men;
tgt_text.4636: that the poor and the helpless always find admittance, not only to your public audiences and tribunals, but even to your house and your bed-chamber;
tgt_text.4637: and that in short, in the whole of your government there is nothing that is spiteful, nothing that is merciless, but that it is filled with clemency, gentleness, and humanity.
tgt_text.4638: How important was that public service you performed when you freed Asia from the unjust and burdensome tax imposed upon them by the ædiles, with great odium to us;
tgt_text.4639: for if one man of quality publicly complains that you have deprived him of almost £100,000, by ordering that money should not be levied for public exhibitions, what vast sums must have been raised, had the custom continued for raising money in the name of all who exhibited public shows at Rome.
tgt_text.4640: I stifled these complaints of our people, by a method which, however it may be regarded in Asia, is highly ap- plauded at Rome ;
tgt_text.4641: for when the states of ray province had voted a sum of money for erecting a temple and a monument to me, and when on account of my great deserts and your extraordinary services, they did it voluntarily and cheer- fully, and though the law has expressly provided, " That governors may receive money for erecting a temple or a monument," nay, though the money which was granted was not to perish, but to be laid out upon the ornaments of a temple, that was to appear to future times, not more a pre- sent to me than to the people of Rome, and to the immortal gods;
tgt_text.4642: and yet I thought that the offer should be rejected though warranted by dignity, by law, and by the good will of those who made it;
tgt_text.4643: and this I did for this reason, amongst others, that those magistrates to whom such sums are not due, nor permitted by law, might bear (the refusal of them) with a more resigned temper.
tgt_text.4644: Apply yourself, therefore, with all your spirit and all your zeal, to that plan which you have already practised, that of loving the people which your country has committed and en- trusted to your faithful care ;
tgt_text.4645: protecting them in every way, and desiring that they should be as happy as possible.
tgt_text.4646: *But if fortune had set you over the Africans, the Spaniards, or the Gauls, those fierce and barbarous nations, yet still it would have been the dictate of your humanity to study their interests, and to have promoted their advantage and welfare.
tgt_text.4647: But when we govern a set of men, among whom civilization not only exists, but from whom it may be supposed even to have extended to others, surely we are most especially bound to repay them what we have received from them ;
tgt_text.4648: for I am not ashamed to acknowledge, especially in my position in life, and with the deeds which I have per- formed, which can involve no suspicion of indolence or un- steadiness ;
tgt_text.4649: that I have arrived at all those accomplishments to which I have attained, by means of those studies and arts which have been handed down to us in the remains and sys- tems of Greece.
tgt_text.4650: Therefore, besides the common faith which we owe to all mankind, we seem to be especially in- debted to this race of men,* so that we should be desirous of offering to those, by whose precepts we have been instructed, that which we learned from them.
tgt_text.4651: Plato, that philosopher, so distinguished by his genius and learning, thought that states would then at length be happy, when either wise and learned men should begin to be their rulers, or when their governors should apply themselves wholly to the study of learning and wisdom ;
tgt_text.4652: that is, he thought that this union of power and wisdom would constitute the safety of states.
tgt_text.4653: This may possibly, at some time, be the case of our whole empire, but at present it is the case of one province, that an individual possesses the supreme power in it, who has de- voted, from his childhood, the largest amount of time and study to the pursuit of learning, of virtue, and humanity.
tgt_text.4654: Take care, therefore, my Quintus, that this year which is added to your government, prove to be a year that is added to the welfare of Asia ;
tgt_text.4655: and because Asia has been more successful in detaining you than I was in procuring your recall, do you behave so as that my regret may receive some mitigation from the joy of the province.
tgt_text.4656: For if you have so indefatigably applied yourself to deserve greater honours than perhaps ever man did, you ought to exert much greater diligence in maintaining them.
tgt_text.4657: I have already given you my sentiments concerning that kind of honours.
tgt_text.4658: I have always been of opinion, that if they are commonly accessible they are worthless ;
tgt_text.4659: if bestowed to serve a purpose, they are con- temptible;
tgt_text.4660: but if they are offered (as has been done) as a t ibute to your merits, I think you cannot bestow too much pains upon their preservation.
tgt_text.4661: As, therefore, you are invested with the highest command and power in those cities where you see your virtues are consecrated and deified, think, in all that you arrange, and decree, and perform, what you owe to such opinions on the part of mankind, to such flattering decisions, and such ex- alted honours.
tgt_text.4662: The result of this will be, that you will pro- vide for all, that you will remedy the ills of your subjects, provide for their welfare, and desire to be designated and regarded as the parent of Asia.
tgt_text.4663: To this zeal and assiduity the farmers of the revenue offer a great obstruction.
tgt_text.4664: If we oppose them, we shall separate from ourselves and from the state an order of men who have the highest claims upon us, and who by me were attached to the service of our government.
tgt_text.4665: If, on the other hand, we should indulge them in every respect, we must suffer those to be utterly ruined, whose welfare, nay, whose convenience, we are bound to consult.
tgt_text.4666: This, if we will view the case aright, is the sole difficulty in all your administration.
tgt_text.4667: For to practise self-control, to subdue all inordinate desires, to regulate your family, to practise the impartial administra- tion of justice, to show yourself ready to acquaint yourself with cases, and to admit and grant a hearing to individuals, are things more glorious than difficult, for they consist not in any laborious application, but in the bent of the mind and of the affections.
tgt_text.4668: We learned how much bitterness of feeling this matter of the farmers of the revenue occasioned to our allies from our own fellow countrymen ;
tgt_text.4669: who, when the tolls of Italy were lately abolished, complained not so much of the heaviness of the tolls as of the insolence of the toll-gatherers, from which I am sensible of what must befall our allies in remote coun- tries, when I have heard such complaints from our fellow citizens in Italy.
tgt_text.4670: It seems to require a superhuman virtue, that is, one like your own, in this situation of things, to give satisfaction to the farmers of the public revenue, especially when the taxes have been disadvantageously contracted for, and at the same time not to suffer our allies to be ruined.
tgt_text.4671: But, in the first place, as to the Greeks, the hardship which they most bitterly complain of, that of their being taxed, is, in my opinion, no great hardship, because by their own constitutions, apart from the government of the Roman people, they were in the same condition with their own cou- sent.
tgt_text.4672: As to the name of a farmer of the revenue, the Greeks- ought not to hold it in such contempt, because, without their assistance, they could not have paid the tax indiscriminately imposed upon them by Sylla.
tgt_text.4673: Now that the Greeks are fully as severe as our farmers are, in the collection of the public revenue, may be concluded from this, that the Caunians* some time ago, who inhabit the islands that were annexed by Sylla to the division of Rhodes, petitioned the senate that they might pay their taxes to us, rather than to the Rho- dians.
tgt_text.4674: They therefore who always have been taxed, ought not to hold the name of a tax-gatherer with horror, nor ought they to despise him, without whom they cannot pay their taxes ;
tgt_text.4675: nor ought they who have petitioned for him to reject him.
tgt_text.4676: The Asiatics ought at the same time to reflect, that were they not under our government, no calamity of foreign war and domestic dissension would ever have been absent from them.
tgt_text.4677: And since this government cannot be supported without taxes, they ought cheerfully to purchase for themselves, with some part of their incomes, an uninter- rupted peace and tranquillity.
tgt_text.4678: When once they come to en- dure with patience the profession and name of a farmer of the revenue, your prudent measures and conduct will be able to make other annoyances seem lighter to them.
tgt_text.4679: They will come, not to reflect so much in making their compositions upon the Censorian Law, but rather upon the advantage of settling the business, and upon their freedom from molesta- tion.
tgt_text.4680: You can likewise continue what you have always so admirably done, to put them in mind how much dignity there is in the office of a farmer of the revenue, andhow much we owe to that order.
tgt_text.4681: So that, apart from force and the influence of authority, and of the fasces, you will bring the publicans into favour and credit with the Greeks.
tgt_text.4682: You may even entreat those whom you have so highly obliged, and who owe their all to you, that by their compliance they will suffer us to cherish and continue those intimate con- nexions that subsist between us and the farmers of the revenue.
tgt_text.4683: But why do I exhort you to those measures which you are not only able to do of your own accord without the iu-- structions of any one, but which in a great degree you already have happily executed.
tgt_text.4684: For the most honourable and considerable bodies of our empire never cease to pay me their daily thanks, which are the more agreeable, because the Greeks do the same.
tgt_text.4685: Now it is a matter of great difficulty to bring together in good will those whose in- terests, whose advantages, and whose natures, I had almost said, are repugnant.
tgt_text.4686: But what I have here written, I have written not for your instruction (for wisdom such as yours stands in need of no man's instructions), but the recording of yeur merits delights me as I write.
tgt_text.4687: In this letter, how- ever, I have been longer than I intended or supposed that I should be.
tgt_text.4688: There is one thing which I shall not cease to recommend to you, for so far as in me lies I will not suffer an exception to your praises.
tgt_text.4689: All who come from that region, while they praise your virtue, your integrity, and your humanity, even in their highest commendations make one exception, your anger;
tgt_text.4690: a vice, which in private and every day life seems to be the defect of an inconstant and weak mind ;
tgt_text.4691: but when a passionate behaviour is joined to sovereign power, nothing can be more monstrous.*
tgt_text.4692: I shall not, however, endeavour to give you the sentiments of the best instructed men, concern- ing the passion of anger, both because I am unwilling thia.
tgt_text.4693: this letter should be too long, and because you can easily learn them from the writings of many men.
tgt_text.4694: Still I do not think that one thing which is proper to a letter should be neglected, namely, that he to whom we write should be made acquainted with those things of which he is ignorant.
tgt_text.4695: Now I am told almost by every body, that when you are free from anger, nothing can be more agreeable than you are ;
tgt_text.4696: ut when the impudence or perverseness of another has excited you, you are under such violent agitations that your kindly disposition is sought for in vain.
tgt_text.4697: As, therefore, a certain desire of glory as well as interest, and fortune, have concurred to lead us into that walk of life, by which we become the perpetual subject of conversation amongst mankind, we ought to do and to strive all we can that no conspicuous vice may be said to attach to us.*
tgt_text.4698: I do not now insist on this consideration, that in human nature at large, and especially at our time of life, it is very difficult for a man to alter his disposition, or suddenly to pluck out a fail- in-, that has settled into a habit.
tgt_text.4699: But my advice to you is this, if you cannot altogether avoid this, but passion takes possession of your mind before reason can take precautions that it should not invade it, you should undergo a course of preparation, and be every day meditating that resistance must be offered to anger, and the more violently it affects the mind, the more diligently must you restrain your tongue ;
tgt_text.4700: which merit sometimes appears to me not less than that of never being angry at all;
tgt_text.4701: because the latter virtue is not solely the proof of self-respect, but sometimes of a lethargic temperament.
tgt_text.4702: But when you are touched with anger, to control both your temper and your language, even to hold your peace, and to keep under command all excitement and irritation of mind ;
tgt_text.4703: these are the properties, if not of con- summate wisdom, yet of extraordinary understanding.
tgt_text.4704: They say that in this respect you are become much more pliable and gentle.
tgt_text.4705: None of your violent emotions of passion are stated to me ;
tgt_text.4706: none of your imprecating expressions, and opprobious behaviour, all which are as repugnant to authority and dignity, as they are reproachful to learning and good breeding.
tgt_text.4707: For if angry passions are implacable, the utmost cruelty is involved, and if placable,* an excess of weakness;
tgt_text.4708: which, however, as a comparison of evils, is pre- ferable to the cruelty.
tgt_text.4709: That the first year of your government gave rise to a great deal of talk upon this subject might be owing to your un- expectedly encountering that injustice, avarice, and insolence of individuals, which seemed intolerable.
tgt_text.4710: The second year, however, was more gentle ;
tgt_text.4711: because both habit and reason, and, if I mistake not, my letters rendered you more mild and patient.
tgt_text.4712: Now your third year ought to admit of such amendment, as that no person may be able to utter the slightest reproach.
tgt_text.4713: And on this subject I address you in the terms neither of exhortation nor precept, but of brotherly entreaty, that you employ your whole abilities, care, and concern, in accumu- latin- praise from all quarters.*
tgt_text.4714: If our situation were one of mediocrity as to public conversation and discourse, nothing pre-eminent would be required of you, nothing beyond the ordinary conduct of others.
tgt_text.4715: But by reason of the splendour and magnitude of the concerns in which we are engaged, unless we derive the highest glory from these functions, we seem scarcely capable of avoiding the deepest condemnation.
tgt_text.4716: We are so situated, that while all good men arc our friends, they also require and expect from us, all application and virtue;
tgt_text.4717: in the meanwhile, all the repro- bate part of mankind, because with them we have declared eternal war, seem to be satisfied with the slightest ground for condemning us.
tgt_text.4718: Wherefore, since such a theatre as Asia has been assigned you for the display of your virtues, a theatre most celebrated by fame, most ample in extent, most distinguished by dis- cernment, but.
tgt_text.4719: naturally so noisy that its expressions and intimations reach even to Rome, I pray you to strive and labour to appear, not only adequate to these conditions, but by your merits to have surpassed them all ;
tgt_text.4720: and as fortune has fixed my share of the public administration in Rome, and yours in Asia, while I yield to none in my conduct, do you excel all in yours.
tgt_text.4721: At the same time reflect, that we are not now labouring for a glory that is in expectation and reversion ;
tgt_text.4722: but we are struggling for what has been attained, a glory that we are not so much to covet as to preserve.
tgt_text.4723: Indeed, had I any interest that is distinct from yours, I could desire nothing more than that situation of life which has actually been assigned to me ;
tgt_text.4724: but as the case is, that unless all your words and actions are answerable to my conduct here, I shall think that I have gained nothing by all those mighty toils and dangers in all which you have been a sharer.
tgt_text.4725: Now if you were my chief fellow labourer in working my way to this splendid reputation, you ought to labour beyond others that I may maintain it.
tgt_text.4726: You are not to regard the opinion and the judgment of those who are now living, but also of those who shall here- after exist, whose verdict will be the more just as it will be free from detraction and malevolence.
tgt_text.4727: In the next place, you are to reflect, that you are not seeking glory for yourself alone ;
tgt_text.4728: and, if you were, you would not be indifferent about it, especially as you have thought proper to consecrate the memory of your name by the noblest memorials, but you are to share it with me, and it is to descend to our posterity
tgt_text.4729: You are therefore to beware, lest if you should be careless you should seem not only to have neglected your own interests, but to have acted grudgingly even to your de- scendants.
tgt_text.4730: And these things are said, not that my words may seem to have aroused you when slumbering, but that they may en- courage you in your career ;
tgt_text.4731: for you will continually act as you have acted, so that all may praise your equity, your moderation, your inflexibility, and your integrity.
tgt_text.4732: But through my excessive affection for you, I am possessed with an insatiable passion for your glory.
tgt_text.4733: In the meanwhile I am of opinion, that as you must be now as well acquainted with Asia as any man is with his own house ;
tgt_text.4734: * and as so great experience has been added to your great wisdom, there is nothing that pertains to glory of which you are not fully sensible, and which does not daily occur to your mind, without the exhortation of any.
tgt_text.4735: But I who, when I read your letters, think I hear you, and when I write to you think I converse with you, am more delighted with your letters the longer they are, and for the same reason I myself also am more prolix in writing.
tgt_text.4736: In conclusion I exhort and entreat you, that just as good poets and skilful actors are wont to do, so you will redouble your attention at this the latter part and conclusion of your business and office ;
tgt_text.4737: that this last year of your government, like the last act of a play, may appear the most elaborate and perfect.
tgt_text.4738: This you will most easily do, if you think that I, whom individually you have endeavoured to please more than all the world besides, am ever present with you, and take an interest in all that you do or say.
tgt_text.4739: Lastly, I entreat you, as you value my welfare, and that of all your friends, that you will most carefully attend to your health.
